title: Pre-Seasoned Cast Iron Dutch Oven Pot with Lid, for Braising, Broiling, Frying, Sourdough Bread Baking, Camping Cookware, BBQ,3 Quart Pan
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Very study, good quality üëç', 'author': 'wenyu liu', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Great item and the price was fair, perfect size for everyday use. Ideal for a small camping kit. Value exceeded the price by all expectations.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Good Product, will need some work, Its worth the price', 'author': 'Spudhut', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I have the 1.5 qt pot. 4 to 3.5 stars for size, Casting I would give 2 stars.If you like your pots as rough as your bed liner, this is the way to go. Everything next to the sun will stick to it.There is a way to get it down to a nice smooth finish, it will take a little work. I put in an hour of time of sanding with a small 40 grit flap disk and an 80 grit scotch pad on a small air grinder, hand sanded with 220 and it came out really smooth. I didn't want to get too crazy and grind this down all the way down, the pits are very small to the touch, my fingernail does not catch or make a grinding noise.It's a nice sized small pot, should season up well. I will likely get another to have 2 in the stall.Hope this helps", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Should last a lifetime.', 'author': 'woodnknoll', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Well made and sturdy. The cast iron is heavy for the size, but note that 1.5 quarts isn't much volume. The mouth of the pot is smaller than my hand, and it's only a few inches deep.Quality wise, it has heft and pre-seasoning, but I don't know what the seasoning is, so I'll probably strip it and re-season it with my choice of oil. The lid is where I see the least amount of finish. The handle is not uniform, and it's not truly flat, so it doesn't sit flush with the rim of the pot. Other than that though, if not a show-piece, it definitely is hardy enough to take around camping or if you have need of a small Dutch oven at home.It's packaged well/securely, and it seems to have a very competitive price range. title: 5.5 Quart Enameled Cast Iron Dutch Oven, 2-In-1 Enamel Oven with Skillet Lid for Grill, Stovetop, Induction (Gray Green)
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The Dutch Oven Masterpiece: A Culinary Love Affair', 'author': 'Shanilda Jones-Walker', 'rating': 5, 'content': "When it comes to cookware that truly stands out, my newly acquired Dutch oven has become an absolute game-changer in my kitchen. From perfectly baked bread to a plethora of mouthwatering stews and meals, this versatile pot has transformed my culinary journey like never before.The first thing that captured my heart was its stunning design and build quality. Crafted with meticulous attention to detail, this Dutch oven feels sturdy and robust. The heavy-duty cast iron material ensures even heat distribution, making it perfect for a wide range of cooking techniques. Whether I'm simmering, braising, frying, or baking, this pot consistently delivers exceptional results.But what truly sets this Dutch oven apart is its exceptional bread-making abilities. I must admit, I am head over heels in love with the crusty artisanal loaves it produces. The tight-fitting lid creates a moist environment inside, allowing the bread to rise beautifully and develop that coveted crispy crust. Baking has never been so enjoyable, and I find myself experimenting with different bread recipes, eagerly anticipating each new creation.Aside from its stellar bread-making prowess, the Dutch oven has become my go-to tool for whipping up an array of hearty meals. From classic beef bourguignon to rich and flavorful vegetable stews, it consistently produces dishes that are packed with depth and taste. The heat retention is superb, and I love how I can transition seamlessly from stovetop to oven, further enhancing the flavors of my concoctions.Moreover, the Dutch oven's versatility knows no bounds. Its lid doubles as a frying pan, adding yet another dimension to its functionality. Whether it's frying eggs, searing meat, or saut√©ing vegetables, the lid-turned-frying-pan performs flawlessly, saving me time and effort in the kitchen. It's like having two incredible pieces of cookware in one!The roomy interior of the Dutch oven can handle large batches of soups, chilis, and even pot roasts, making it an ideal companion for family gatherings and dinner parties. And the fact that I can seamlessly use the lid as a frying pan only adds to its allure.As with any kitchen tool, there's a slight learning curve involved. Initially, I struggled to gauge the perfect cooking times and temperatures, but with practice and some experimentation, I quickly became acquainted with the Dutch oven's capabilities.In conclusion, my Dutch oven has undoubtedly become an essential staple in my kitchen, and I'm head over heels for its exceptional performance. From heavenly bread to a wide array of delectable meals, this versatile pot has proven its worth time and time again. The added bonus of the lid doubling as a frying pan has made it even more indispensable. If you're a food enthusiast looking to take your culinary skills to new heights, investing in a high-quality Dutch oven is an absolute must. Trust me; it will undoubtedly spark a love affair with your cooking like you've never experienced before.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 23, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love the color', 'author': 'Linda Smith', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This Dutch oven has dual uses, the lid is also a cooking vessel. title: Goodful All-In-One Pot, Multilayer Nonstick, High Performance Cast Dutch Oven With Matching Lid, Roasting Rack And Turner, Made Without PFOA, Dishwasher Safe Cookware, 4.7-Quart, Linen
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great, versatile pan‚ÄîThis is a life saver for those with arthritis or arm weakness', 'author': "J. O'Donnell", 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I purchased this for my mother-in-law since she has arthritis in her hands and can‚Äôt lift anything heavy. This pan is incredibly light and it‚Äôs become a favorite with everyone who cooks in this kitchen. It holds a lot, cooks evenly and even gets clean in the dishwasher. I can‚Äôt say enough good things about this pan. You won‚Äôt be sorry if you purchase it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars SO glad I found these!', 'author': 'P Gilroy', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I was searching for a dupe for a more expensive all-use pan and Google led me to this one. Since I typically like certain types of pots/pans for certain uses, I was happy to note that there was not only a saut√© pan, but a Dutch oven style pot as well. I am enjoying both of them.The pot:The handle on the top of this one seems to be some kind of hard plastic, and I think it's because it's supposed to be oven safe. However, it's ONLY oven safe up to 400 degrees for 30 minutes per the instruction guide. It has smaller metal handles on each side that DO get HOT, so you'll want to have some kind of potholders or mitts at the ready when handling it. The sage green color is beautiful, and the nonstick surface on the inside of the pot is very smooth. Like many others, I cannot help wondering what it is made of, and I really hope that it is safe, because I plan to use these for many years to come if possible. I tend to cook soups, stews and chilis in a Dutch oven style pot, and this one has been extremely easy to use AND clean. It doesn't require a lot of heat to get going, and once it does I typically have to turn it down a bit. The nonstick surface is fabulously easy to clean, and I DO season the surface prior to storing it away. I also seasoned it prior to first use per the instruction guide. I have cooked chili, red beans and chicken soup, all with zero issues.The pan:This is a lovely piece of cookware to have on hand for saut√©ing and browning. It features a long soft touch handle on one side and a smaller metal handle on the other. Like the pot, you will want to have a mitt or potholder readily available if you plan to touch the smaller handle. The sage color is a perfect match to that of the pot. As many others have stated, it is pretty deep. I have cooked butter chicken and nacho meat and also boiled macaroni (and made the cheese sauce) in this one. All of the dishes came out perfectly, and the pan was super easy to clean. I also season the pan after use.I use silicone utensils to cook with, as I am not a fan of wooden spoons or spatulas.I noticed a bit of discoloration on the bottom of the pan after first use, and I'm not sure whether it was from letting water dry on it or what. I was able to use a cleaning paste to restore it, so I think that I will do this from time to time if I notice any further problems in the future. I also handwash these pots and will probably not put them in the dishwasher. I plan to provide an update in 3 months or so, since that is when several others have noticed issues with the cookware. As for now, I am totally in love with them and hope that that they will last for years to come.Update 1/14/2023: I no longer season the pan after each use and it is still beautifully nonstick. I'm still in love!Update: 1/28/2023: The underside of the handle of the saut√© pan is singed, as I have a gas stove. I do not have the flames up high, but somehow the heat has gotten to it. Hopefully this will not effect the performance in the long run, but it COULD compromise the integrity of the handle over time.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 25, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This pan is amazing! Easy to cook with and very easy to clean!!', 'author': 'Christine O.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Bought this kind of on a whim.... its one of my favorite pans. It is large and takes up some real estate in the cabinet, but well worth it!! Distributes heat evenly, cooks up meals so well. It is super easy to clean!!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best cookware', 'author': 'Pamela', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Love this cookware! title: Lodge Seasoned Cast Iron Deep Camp Dutch Oven - 12 Inch / 8 Quart
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Back to basics...', 'author': 'Kai Tiura', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This Dutch oven purchase was my first. As with everything I get into, I immediately wanted to read up on them. I had no idea how great these things were! First, the history of the Dutch ovens alone should tell you they are no passing fad and have more than enough usefulness to qualify them on anybody\'s must-have list. They have been providing excellent, simple-to-cook meals for people since the days of the wagon trains. Cooking with charcoal makes the process so easy and cheap and the versatility of the Dutch oven allows it to go from griddle to saute pan to pot to oven by just changing up what you use and how you use it. The lid, inverted, is a griddle. This model\'s lid rim (a design attribute attributed to Paul Revere no less!) is raised to hold coals on top to aid in browning of foods (heat rises, so it\'s hard to brown the top unless you have coals on the lid).Lodge is now producing cast iron cookware that is pre-seasoned, saving you the step of seasoning it before using for the first time. A quick rinse and dry right out of the box and I was cooking. I did a chicken pot pie recipe that was super easy and used refrigerated crescent rolls, rolled out flat, for the crust. A fair amount of coals underneath at first to crank up the heat and pre-cook the chicken and then saute the onions and start the potatoes. Throw in the rest of the ingredients and get to a boil, stirring occasionally, then take a few of the bottom coals and put them on the lid, lowering the bottom heat and getting that important top heat going, then just place the unrolled crescent rolls on top, cover and let it bake. So-o-o-o good!!! Last night I did tamale pie for a party we went to. With hamburger and some homemade Chilean Langaniza sausage I\'d made, I added some corn, Ortegas, olives, bell pepper, enchilada sauce, garlic, freshly ground coarse black pepper and chili powder. That cooked for a while and I mixed up some corn meal with milk and eggs, poured it over the hot food, covered with shredded cheese and cooked until done. Outstanding! The pot was emptied while all the rest of the food got token pickings. There is something about cast iron-cooked food... and it\'s healthier for you than Teflon.I love barbecue, cooking "low and slow" to get that tenderness and smoky flavor into my \'cue, and this oven allows that same principle to be incorporated (without the smoke, of course) in just about any meal. You need to nurture the coals during any cooking session, so someone must be there to tend them if you cook at really low temps, but that\'s about the only drawback, and most people will never do that anyway. I bought the metal table with windbreaker sides from Lodge and can\'t wait to use it. I cooked my first meal on my concrete patio and, while it worked great, it will be nice to get the oven up so I don\'t have to stoop to the ground to tend coals and stir/check contents, etc. I cooked the second meal under the shade of my canopy as it was sunny and warm, and I threw down a concrete paver that is about 2\' x 2\' and it worked great too... but I really want to use that new table!Cooking a huge amount? I got the 12" oven and it\'ll cook enough food for at least ten people in one swoop, and you can always buy the 12 qt. oven that will supply a single pot of food for a huge group but if you need to cook with multiple ovens at the same time, simply stack them. Once you get used to the cleanup method of NO SOAP and get your process down, it is really easy to clean up after cooking too. These products are simply incredible and I wish I had known more details about them before. They last for generations; people actually pass them on to their children. Looking forward to a long relationship with this product!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 13, 2011', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Cooks wonderfully and easy to maintain (See Tips)', 'author': 'YuenX', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The media could not be loaded. I was a cast iron denier for years because I read so much about the difficulty of maintaining it -- and for the fact that it is so heavy. I started experimenting with a no-name brand a year ago and got the hang of it until the bottom of its coating started flaking. I immediately went to by a Lodge instead and have been happy with the decision.I have since purchased a Dutch Oven version and it\'s been wonderful for camping. The remainder of this review is based on what I wrote about the Lodge 10" pan, but the same principles apply here.Pan is already pre-seasoned and smooth (compared to the no-name one), and maintenance has been really simple: after cooking, put water on the pan and heat it up. Then scrub with metal (chainmail scrubber) or wood to get the gunk off. Drain, rinse, heat up again to evaporate all the water, then apply a thin film of oil.If you have JUST received the pan, it\'s best to use bacon to season it per Lodge\'s instructions.We have made many meals with the cast iron and I use it for practically everything. Just put some olive oil or butter while heating up the pan slowly until desired temperature and cook.Maintains heat very well.Skip the silicone handle as that is NOT reliable at all -- started falling apart after just a couple months of usage. I just use a towel to hold the hot handle.Lid is a must for camping. I also like the Lodge "A5-11" tool to lift the lid with.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 26, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A must for every camper', 'author': 'Sir  reads a lot', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'If you enjoy cooking over an open fire, then this needs to be in your camping equipment. So versatile we‚Äôve made everything from stews and soups to baked goods in ours. Phenomenal results every time.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Good Quality', 'author': 'Barb', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Good quality nice and heavy just what I needed for camp fires', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 17, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Completes my Dutch Oven Tower', 'author': 'Kelly Kennedy', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Updated with a photo 7-15-2020. My grandmother\'s Martin cowboy skillet/spider skillet is on bottom, a Camp Chef No 10 in the middle, the Lodge No 8 on top. Top two have biscuits in them, bottom had a breakfast casserole. The Lodge lives up to Lodge\'s reputation. Very pleased with it.***Bought from the Amazon Warehouse as an open box or perhaps returned. Arrived in a few days. Packaged in original box but it had been opened and taped shut with that scotch tape that has strings in it, so not by Amazon. It had the original box, packaging, and cookbook/owners manual with it. My 2 year old granddaughter had me read it to her over coffee yesterday - to each their own I guess***I inherited my grandmother\'s 80 year old 12" spider skillet (looks like a footed dutch oven, only with a long pan handle instead of a bail) early last year. Being big on camping with my horses and friends and family and THEIR horses, I wanted to learn to cowboy cook. A few youtube videos and some reading later, I baked my first 5 layer breakfast casserole at camp last Easter in my grandmother\'s skillet, I was hooked on camp cooking, specifically with all the cast iron I inherited. Later last year, my dad made a tripod for me at his welding shop out of electrical conduit, complete with adjustable chain and hook. An scavenged charcoal grill grate with chains allows me to grill over the camp fire or keep the coffee warm.Back to the dutch ovens - I now own a previously owned 14" no name (base of the tower) my grandmother\'s 12", a Camp Chef 10" and this Lodge 8". I have not used it yet.Lid fits tight, no wobble (Unlike the camp chef) and the feet are sturdy, substantially sized (Unlike my 14", which has thin, almost spindly looking feet). I found no imperfections in it. Seasoning is good, but obviously a very light starter coat.I would say this size is good for small things, like a small pan of cornbread, a small (Or just a deeper) peach cobbler, perhaps some camp taters (Canned sliced potatoes, bacon, onion, can of cream of mushroom, cheese), a side dish, something like that.Looking forward to', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 24, 2020', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Lodge quality - now go and cook!', 'author': 'Tezza', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I wanted to try out campfire cooking so I did a little research and purchased this Lodge dutch oven.Let me first say that I have bought other Lodge cast iron products and they are the "Mercedes" of cast iron cookware. No shortcuts here, just beautiful, functional cast iron products that can be passed down to your children or grandchildren. On to the review...The pot lid is very, very heavy. The pot itself is beautifully made. The instructions are clear (I recommend you follow them, they are correct). The iron handle is robust enough to take the pot off the fire filled hot food without giving you any concern.The pot is "pre-seasoned" so all you have to do is give it a quick clean. I usually clean my cast iron products using hot water, a soft plastic brush and a little salt. Not much sticks anyway, but the salt works to give the brush a little "bite", plus I think the salt helps the seasoning a little.The next step is to make a nice fire about 2 hours ahead of your cook time. The pot is NOT placed on the fire directly, but a few hot coals are dragged away from the fire for cooking.I place the pot over about 10 hot coals on the botton, and about 20 hot coals on the lid. I turn the lid every 15 minutes or so and replace the coals with new ones about every 45 minutes.Generally this method will cook a 4-5 pound chicken with a few potatoes, carrots and onions until it "falls off the bone" in about 3 hours.It\'s really hard to describe how chicken tastes after being cooked over fire coals. It seems to keep the character flavor of the pot from meal to meal, and tastes ever so slightly smoky. It\'s very similar to cooking I\'ve tasted in New Zealand where meat and vegetables are wrapped up on palm fronds, place over white hot stones, then buried for about four hours. It just has it\'s own unique flaor.I\'ve also cooked chile, leg of lamb and a number of other dishes. They\'ve all been great.A word of warning. Most people (including myself) can\'t believe that just a few coals below the pot, and double the number placed on top of the lid, can really cook the contents, but less is truly more in campfire cooking.If too many coals are used, the food will taste strangely overcooked, but not burned. So best to exercise much restraint.If you want to try campfire cooking and buy quality that can last for generations, then I say buy this quality pot and go out and cook!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 15, 2008', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Great, but needed work', 'author': 'RnR', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I bought a 12" (8 qt) "Used -- Very Good" return to save a few bucks (Cast iron never wears out, right? It can ALWAYS be cleaned and re-seasoned). It arrived in brand-new, never-used condition, but it was obvious to me why it was returned once I opened it. The inside had a horrible sand-cast finish that almost looked like mill scale buildup on hot rolled steel. I was disappointed because I have high regards for Lodge Manufacturing and the products that they turn out. I don\'t know what standard they use to determine when a cast product is too rough and should be scrapped, but this one needed (at the very least) to be resurfaced on the inside of the bottom. The same roughness would have been fine on the outside or even the lid, but the bottom and sides should be smooth.I was too excited to get it and didn\'t want to waste time returning it, so I spent about 20-30 minutes scrubbing it with emory paper (starting with 80 grit and working down to 320) and it\'s fine now. Truth be told, the bottom is much smoother than the outisde now. Of course it needs to be re-seasoned, but having bought a used (return) in order to save money, I was planning on re-seasoning it anyway.Lodge makes great products; please don\'t let me give you the wrong impression on this DO. Aside from the casting errors in this particular DO, I was highly pleased. The wall thickness is plenty stout to endure camping life, yet not overly heavy. The legs are beefy and taper into the bottom with a generous blend. The lid fits beautifully and the pre-seasoning looks great for what it was intended. Had I not needed to resurface the bottom, I would easily give it 5 stars. Now that it\'s smooth, I expect years and years of happy camping with it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 8, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love it', 'author': 'Holly Erling', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I use this in coals in a fire pit for cakes, biscuits, and casseroles. It cooks evenly and does not cause scorching.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars omg i can cook!', 'author': 'hadar tomer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'always have been a fan of lodge pans.but this is better. usually i ...dont cook more than a steak. after a long offroad adventure I decided to give this a try. cut the steak. some potatos. garlic. olive oil and a nice bed of coals on top.after 5 minutes it started to sizzle. 20 minutes later the smell was hard to resist. 40 minutes later- wow. I am so sorry i didnt het a bigger one cause we ate it all in 10 minutes and we were just 3 guys.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 12, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars No cookbook included as advertized', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Really excited about the camp Dutch oven. However, I was VERY DISAPPOINTED that the cookbook was not included as advertised.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Lodge 3 Quart Enameled Cast Iron Dutch Oven with Lid ‚Äì Dual Handles ‚Äì Oven Safe up to 500¬∞ F or on Stovetop - Use to Marinate, Cook, Bake, Refrigerate and Serve ‚Äì Island Spice Red
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The PERFECT Braiser for smaller scale recipes!', 'author': 'Amazon Shopper', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I am a skilled, passionate home cook and also a Lodge fan. I have multiple other Lodge cast iron pieces and needed a slightly smaller braiser that was still deep enough for actual braising (many smaller pots I\'ve seen are either sauce pans or more like saute pan size). After a few "order and return/exchange" spats I FINALLY found the one. This pan is perfect. The price was great compared to many other brands. I cook for myself and my son most often but about half the week (if not more) I prepare dinners for my parents and my sister as well (we all live together). This pan is great for one-pot meals for myself and my son (usually with leftovers for a lunch or a dinner later in the week) but also works perfectly for preparing sauces, rice, or vegetables to go with the larger meals I prepare. Heat retention and conductivity is amazing, love the heft of the cast iron, and LOVE the beautiful ombre red color. No one needed to sell me further on Lodge products but after a fourth amazing purchase it has really reassured me that I have found the only cast iron brand I need!!!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 16, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Much Better and Versatile than I Thought', 'author': 'Snowbunny', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I read the reviews, watched many product review videos on enameled cast-iron dutch ovens and pondered on the product for weeks and finally decided to purchase this pot. I think it was on sale too.I am happy with the purchase.Luckily, my pot was in good condition; no chipping, cracking, warping, denting or visible signs of uneven glazing. The 3qt. size is a good size for my weekly batch cooking. (Your mileage may vary) Since it is pretty heavy, this is also the limit at which I could lift and wash the vessel. Speaking of washing, this pot cleans so well. So far no burning, no sticking and any fond that has formed while cooking deglazes right away.I have cooked various rice (white, brown, wild, fried), pastas, lentil/bean soups, chicken tacos, braised chicken, paella, soda bread and even Moroccan chicken dish for tagine. As you can see from the line-up of food I made, this little dutch oven can take place of bunch of other cooking vessels. This versatile pot, along with my Instant Pot and beloved stainless steel pot set, will let me cook multiple dishes all at once. (That saves a lot of time for the weekend batch cooker)If I could make a request or two to Lodge, that would be, please make it lighter. It IS VERY heavy. And please consider making pots in the slightly shallower shapes too, but not as flat as a braiser. I totally love the round-ish profile of Lodge dutch ovens (much more than Le Creuset designs), but since I use a small oven, height of 5 1/2" and above won\'t work well. For those dishes I need to keep the lid on while baked in the oven, I am currently using a Le Creuset pot.Overall, this product is nice to look at, reasonably priced and works very well and I recommend it.11/10/2020 Little Update:After months of daily use and it\'s still working great.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 31, 2020', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars These dutch ovens are totally worth it and they are awesome!', 'author': 'Omkara', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I have these Lodge dutch ovens in 3 quart, 4.5 quart, 6 quart and 7.5 quart. I also have the Lodge 3.6 quart cast iron enamel casserole pan. I have had these for about six months and I use them all the time.Lodge never claimed that these dutch ovens are made in America, their cast iron skillets and such are made in America, and I guess if where something is made is what determines whether you like an item, you will most likely not like this dutch oven. I am not sure what some of the reviewers are doing with these dutch ovens that they have started on fire or peeled and cracked really bad. I use my 6 quart dutch oven pretty much every other week and I use one of the others that I own weekly. I take care of them, I don't put them in the dishwasher, which is what causes the enamel to crack, I store them carefully, though I guess not too carefully as they are stacked together, and I don't wash them when they are still hot, but I don't let the food sit in them for extended periods either. I heat them up prior to putting food in them to cook, though I do use high temperatures at times. I put them in the oven almost every time I use them after starting on the stove.These dutch ovens have held up wonderfully and make the most wonderful meals for me and my family. I love them, and they are not super expensive. Seeing as I have five items from Lodge, if there was really something wrong with them, I would assume I would have experienced something by now with at least one of the ovens, and I have not. Don't put them in the dishwasher!! They will not hold up. These are truly wonderful dutch ovens. I make the best pot roasts, short ribs, chicken coq au vin, and more with them.I have made pot roast and beef stew in the 3 quart dutch oven, and it has come out so good, so don't pay attention to the people that say you can't do so with the smaller ovens. You 100% can. I make my elder parents food in the 3 quart all the time, and it the makes perfect amount for them to have a couple of dinners. The 3 quart is also great for baked ziti dishes, bread, and the like. This dutch oven is perfect for a single person to make magnificent meals in.The 4.5 quart dutch oven is also perfect for making pot roasts, stews, and such for a couple of people. It has a little more room than the 3 quart, making it perfect for two people.The 6 quart dutch oven is perfect for making food for my husband and I that we can eat for a few days. It is also great for making food when we have company over. This oven would be perfect for a family of four, though you could also make enough for six without leftovers.The 7.5 quart dutch oven is perfect for a large family. I use this when we are eating with my brother and his children, or we are having several couples over and want left overs. My husband loves leftovers.Finally though it is not in this listing, just as an FYI the 3.6 casserole is perfect for chicken coq au vin, and one pot chicken and rice, and dishes like those. I absolutely love that pan and I use it frequently. I make enough food for four people comfortably, five or six depending on portions. It can fit about 8 chicken thighs with skin and 1 pound baby potatoes or a cup of rice.I hope this helps. This is the only time I have ever written a review this long or detailed. I really love these ovens and find them extremely useful. I like the slow cooker, but it doesn't compare to a dutch oven in the oven slow cooking.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States April 13, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this Dutch Oven! Perfect size!', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I used this pan to make soup. It takes a while, on medium low heat to come up to boil, but when it does...it cooks quickly!The lid fit perfectly! The interior is a little bumpy, but not bad. The pan cooks beautifully! I love it! There is nothing like cooking in a cast iron dutch oven! Having enamel cover the entire pan makes it even better! It cleans ip easily! It is very heavy, but thst is what makes it cook better than other pans.The size is perfect!I made enough dumplings to feed 2 families!It holds more than i thought it would. I can cook a good size roast in it, with lots of potatoes, and vegetables. I will use this for Holidays, and company.I hope it holds up for years. I will update my review in a few months. So far it is great!The rims are enameled too! It is so hard to find an enameled cast iron pan with enameled rims, unless you want to spend a fortune. Good job, Lodge!!!I got the Oyster color. It is beautiful!!!I never use high heat...no need to. I use silicone utensils, and hand wash.Update...i have made so many meals, in this Dutch Oven. It holds soooooo much!!! Chili, Dumplings, Soup, and more! All it takes is a low heat. I start it out on low...3 on my electric stove. After 5 minutes, i turn it up to 4. Then a few minutes later i turn it up to Medium...5. It will come to a boil on 4, and 5. But after it comes to a boil, i turn it down to 3, or 4, because it holds the heat so well. It will keep boiling.Clean up? I still love how easily it cleans up! Stuck on sauce? Just wait til it cools down, add water for about 10 minutes. Then just wash it with some Polmolive Original dish liquid, (no citrus, or citric acid that can dull the shine of the enamel.). It washes like a china plate. Easy! Then i dry it, immediately. I let it sit, without the lid for an hour to air...then i out the little rubber guards on the pan, and put the lid on it. It looks beautiful, sitting out in my kitchen. This is my every day pan. It is the perfect size. Good job, Lodge!Adding photo of my huge pot of dumplings. Looooooove this dutch oven!!!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 13, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect size', 'author': 'ME', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Sturdy, functional and easy to clean. Will last forever.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well Made and Affordable', 'author': 'Mr. Robert Hebron', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I am fortunate enough that much of my cookware is higher end but I bought this as a gift and liked it so much I kept it for myself. Really nice item.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this pot!', 'author': 'alienmurphy', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I especially like the enamel coating. This makes cleaning much easier than with regular cast iron. As with plain cast iron, food cooks much faster and more uniformly.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Works very well for the price', 'author': 'Lily Banks, Painter', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I\'ve had this for 14 months and I use it about once a week for stews and baking round sourdough loaves. I also own a larger size 30-year old Le Creuset dutch oven, so I can compare the two. I\'m only going to address functionality, not the issue of it being made in China instead of the USA. I bought this to have a backup for smaller batches of food. I wanted something much less expensive than a Le Creuset but still sturdy and useful, and I was not disappointed. The pot did not come with any defects that I could find. After a year it is in excellent shape and I don\'t see any reason why it should not last for my lifetime. The Lodge pot is very good for browning and sauteing meats and vegetables, then transferring to the oven. I\'ve had excellent results every time with stews and braised meats. It also works well for round sourdough loaves. It\'s not so good for roasts, as only a small roast or chicken will fit. After a year, the Lodge pot is still clean and slick on the inside although there is now some very slight discoloration on the bottom and some scratching on the outside. When I take the pot out of the oven, I usually leave the lid on for about 20 minutes. This way, the steam gently dissolves any browning on the sides and bottom so I can scrape it all out with a spatula. This usually gets out all the "fond." If there is still anything left sticking, I fill the pot with water and let it soak a few hours, then I can scrub it out with a plastic scrubbing sponge. The pot goes in the dishwasher and I haven\'t observed any rusting on the edge of the lid so far. I use steel wool for burned on grease on the outside. I care for the pot by heating it slowly, and never letting it overheat, or warm up "dry" without oil or water in it. I only use silicone or wood spoons and spatulas in the pot. I never use scouring powder or steel wool to clean the inside. The Lodge\'s main drawback is that the bottom of the pot is too small. The sides curve downward so that the actual flat bottom that sits on the heating element is only 6 inches in diameter, while the diameter of the rim is 9.5 inches. You can only brown a small amount of meat at a time on this surface. I chose a smaller size deliberately but I was disappointed in this feature. The pot can only brown small batches of meat at one time. It is also rather heavy for its size, and yes, it heats unevenly unless you heat it slowly and thoroughly. The Le Creuset is still my favorite to cook with as it has a much larger bottom surface for its proportions, and distributes heat more evenly, although I still take care to heat it slowly. I can brown a much larger batch of meat in one go, and it\'s big enough to hold a roast pork loin or chicken. Also, the Lodge pot is almost as heavy as the Le Creuset although it is smaller, which can make it awkward to handle. On the other hand, the entire Le Creuset line is fabulously expensive (mine was a gift.) I just did not want to spend that much money for a backup pot. This Lodge dutch oven then is a good buy for a small sturdy dutch oven if you are on a budget and are willing to put in the effort to take care of it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this pot!', 'author': 'Wayne', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'We live that you can use it on our induction stovetop and then put it in the oven. Very easy to clean!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect size and looks great quality', 'author': 'Skyline123', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I bought this for baking sourdough bread. I can't wait to use it especially it can be used at 500 degrees.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Staub Cast Iron Dutch Oven 5-qt Tall Cocotte, Made in France, Serves 5-6, Cherry
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Gorgeous, high-quality enameled cast iron Dutch oven, durable + great size & shape...', 'author': 'SuLu', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Staub is one of my favorite cookware brands. I like cast iron and have a lot of it including two enameled cast iron Dutch ovens from well known brands (but they were actually made in China). I inherited one of them from my Dad and purchased the other before I knew about French enameled cast iron cookware in general and Staub in particular. My Dad and I had the idea to compare the two brands and both seemed to be of good quality and they lasted for years, but they were far from perfect -- the enamel on one of them was easily chipped and the interior of the other one developed cracking and the surface started to flake off. In the intervening years, I discovered Staub and started building up a collection; the quality of the materials and workmanship is amazing. They are beautifully finished with several layers of gorgeous enamel (that resists chipping) and they are very heavy with a durable matte black interior. The lids are self-basting. They are pricey so I would usually purchase a different piece for the holidays each year. Sort of a gift to myself. I have two of the figural pieces (the tomato and the pumpkin -- so charming! but useful, too) the medium-sized coq-au-vin, a 3.75 quart French oven and three of the Dutch ovens (4 quart, 5.5 quart and 7 quart). I thought my collection was complete, although I wouldn't have minded if someone gifted me the cute artichoke figural piece). Anyway, I had been using my Dad's Dutch oven as a designated pot for making yogurt, cream of wheat and oatmeal when I noticed the flaking. I liked using it for this purpose because it was taller than my Staub Dutch ovens. I was so happy to see that Staub had introduced a tall version of the 5-quart Dutch oven, and I ordered it in the matte black. It looks great and It is perfect for so many things -- yogurt, of course but also soups and stews or baking bread. The size is versatile and it is just right for smaller families. The price was $199.99 when I purchased mine, and I thought that was a good deal. I have been looking for a Christmas gift for my SIL (a great cook) and I see they are now only $149.99! I also see there are great new colors available, too! This Dutch oven is definitely worth the price as Staub enameled cast iron is gorgeously finished, well-made, robust and durable + everything I make in these pots come out flavorful and delicious. It is 10 times better than the less expensive enameled cast iron I previously used. My older ones still look brand new. I know I will be passing all of my beautiful Staub pieces down to my children and grandchildren someday and I'm sure they will enjoy them using them for years, too.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 10, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars 4 ¬Ω stars: Rough Handles Aside, ‚ÄòGoldilocks‚Äô Cocotte for Midsized Batches of Acidic Soups', 'author': 'East Coast Refugee', 'rating': 5, 'content': "TL;DR SUMMARY RATING:4 ¬Ω stars -- i.e. 5 stars for durability, uniquely useful form-factor (the higher sides really do make a difference), and Staub‚Äôs black ceramic lining‚Äôs trademark imperviousness to prolonged exposure to acidic ingredients; minus ¬Ω star for handles that, while fully sealed against rust and liquids, are disconcertingly rough to the touch.MAIN REVIEW:Don‚Äôt let this cocotte‚Äôs unfinished-feeling handles dissuade you: The Staub 5 Quart Tall Cocotte is fully coated (no bare cast iron) and so ready to bring its unique, stockpot-like shape to non-reactive battle with your most acidic ingredients that it might benefit even folks who already own Staub cocottes of other dimensions/volumes.How do I know? Because while the Staub 5 Quart Tall Cocotte's marriage of a practical, midsized volume and a space-saving, tall, slim, stockpot-like profile has during my 14 months of ownership proven handy for myriad tasks in my small apartment's tiny kitchen -- with the cocotte's tall sides as useful for reducing spatters when roasting or frying as they are for providing extra headroom when braising leafy greens like spinach, collards, or kale -- I bought one mainly to make lemony soups in a smaller, slimmer vessel than the larger Staub cocotte I already owned.Let me explain. During long Great Lakes winters, I make a weekly mega-batch of veggie soup out of bulk-purchased, dried veggies long-simmered in stock, aromatics, olive oil, and spices over low heat for 12 to 18 hours. Critically, at several junctures during this process, I add ample lemon and/or lime juice to help tenderize the rehydrating veggies, brighten and deepen the soup's flavors, and keep my salt usage low.This penchant for long-simmered, citrus-accented soup creates specific cookware needs -- as I discovered almost 10 years ago, when I banished all Teflon-coated cookware from my kitchen for a minimalist, gradually-assembled collection of stainless steel, raw cast iron, carbon steel, and enameled cast iron. I soon learned that while stainless steel and enameled cast iron are generally non-reactive when cooking with acidic ingredients, independent cookware studies and cookware manufacturers' guidance caution that long-simmered recipes heavy on acidic ingredients can cause stainless steel vessels to pit or leach.Thus, back in 2013, I took advantage of an online cookware retailer's clearance sale to snag a ginormous, 9 Quart Staub Cocotte for my weekly mega-batches of citrus-laced veggie soup. Alas, in recent years, having left my office job to work from home, I've found myself wanting to make smaller batches of soup for which my witch's-cauldron-sized, 9 Quart Staub Cocotte -- while still chip-free, rust-free, and gorgeous after nearly a decade of regular use -- is often too capacious, too unwieldy, or too covetous of stovetop real estate when I‚Äôm using other burners simultaneously.Enter Staub's 5 Quart Tall Cocotte -- Staub‚Äôs first stockpot-shaped cocotte -- which I purchased in Matte Black in 2021 (after a 2-year wait for a sale price) because it mimics the slim, space-saving form-factor of my favorite stainless-steel stockpot (i.e. Cuisinart 6-Quart Stockpot w/Cover, Stainless Steel ), sans stainless steel‚Äôs susceptibility to pit or leach when subjected to my citrus-laced soups week after week.And although I initially worried that its unfinished-feeling handles -- which are much rougher to the touch than those of my other Staub enameled cast iron products -- sported exposed cast iron (as many other online consumers have also wondered), the 5 Quart Tall Cocotte‚Äôs handles have indeed proved coated with a durable sealant as sturdy and non-reactive as those on its smooth-handled, Staub 9 Quart Cocotte big sister. No chips, rusting, or wear during the past 14 months of weekly lemony soup nirvana. Score!With the volume of Staub's 4 Quart Cocotte a little too small for my needs, and the squat dimensions of Staub's 5.5 Quart Cocotte wider and lower than the slim, high-sided profile I wanted in a midsized cocotte, Staub's 5 Quart Tall Cocotte provides a 'Goldilocks' form-factor I‚Äôve found ‚Äòjust right.‚Äô YMMV.TL;DR UPSHOT:IMHO after 14 months of regular use of Staub‚Äôs 5 Quart Tall Cocotte, this characteristically durable, versatile, and acidic-ingredient-impervious cocotte is unique enough -- with a form-factor found nowhere else in Staub‚Äôs enameled cast iron line -- that even folks who already own Staub cocottes of other capacities/shapes might consider adding the 5 Quart Tall to their kitchen arsenals. YMMV.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 30, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The Perfect Size', 'author': 'Socalartgal', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I bought this beautiful 7 quart cocotte in the burnt orange color on sale. Was having a hard time deciding between the Staub and the Le Crueset dutch oven and glad I finally decided on the Staub. It is attractive, well-built and extremely easy to clean. The inside is dark gray and will not show stains which was a major complaint I had with Le Crueset. It also has a metal lid topper that withstands the heat well and will not melt. Overall, I think it is slightly superior to the Le Crueset for the reasons stated. The lid also seems to be a tighter fit. I christened this piece with a pot roast on the stove and it turned out perfectly. I'm extremely pleased with my purchase and would not hesitate to purchase other Staub products.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars First time to purchase.', 'author': 'Wayne', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'We have come to love this 9qt for cooking. It works well, fast and easy to clean. We Recommend it. The color is beautiful.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars An excellent all around cook pot and a great value compared to Le Creuset', 'author': 'HonestOpinion', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Made in France, very nice quality, excellent all around size, perfect for making beef Bourgogne or other stews, chilis, soups, etc.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I adore my Staub!', 'author': 'RedStone', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This pot in grenadine is not only gorgeous, it works splendidly, too. I have a 7-quart Lodge cast iron dutch oven which I use regularly, but I needed an enameled pot for acidic dishes. The Lodge has more space for browning than the taller Staub, but the cocotte is perfect for soups, stews, braising, and other slow-cooking dishes. Plus, that beautiful grenadine enamel makes me smile every time I see it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 16, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Most important ? No complaints at all.', 'author': 'Daniel B.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The three meals prepared so far in the Staub have been wonderful.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 20, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars I like this cocotte...', 'author': 'qajaqr', 'rating': 4, 'content': "... for myself. It is just the right size for a small roast or casserole, doesn't take up a lot of counter space and is surprisingly heavy for its appearance. It cooks evenly, holds temperature thru just about any length of meal, assuming it is moved from range to table, and could easily be mistaken for a centerpiece.Now... it is more delicate than one would think a cast iron pot would be. The surface inside is difficult to clean and not dishwasher safe, or at least not recommended. Has to be cleaned by hand and without any abrasives. They'll remove the interior coating which is rough and therefore not easy to clean. The interior coating is also black, meaning it is very difficult to gauge braising or opacity without a light directly overhead. The handles are cast iron and the lid knob is metal. Do not grab either when in service without a pot holder of some kind. If you do, it will be a memorable experience.I have not seen where this $400 pot cooks any better than any of my other cast iron, they are generally easier to clean and the other casseroles have a light colored interior making it much easier to see what is going on in there.While this may be left to someone in a last will and testament, I doubt it would be much more appreciated than any well maintained cast iron vessels, unless the recipient was a cast iron snob or a demanding gourmet chef that truly appreciated its capability and good looks despite its feature shortcomings.I have found after a number of months mine sets in an honored space along with some other shockingly priced cookware while lesser names easier to clean and handle provide the day to day cookery.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 16, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this piece', 'author': 'rosalyn', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'On top the the black interior and design of cover that keeps steam water inside, the tall body is a space saver, for storage, for space on stove and when serving on table. I cooked 5 pounds of stew pork legs with bones for Chinese new year eve dinner. Stuck it in oven, went shower, and it was all done by the time I returned to the kitchen. A beautiful piece! Must have.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars PERFECT SIZE POT', 'author': 'Connie', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This Dutch Oven is so easy to manage with my bad back and is the perfect size for two. I have made a beautiful loaf of sourdough einkorn bread and spaghetti sauce. This is definitely one of my favorite pots.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 15, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Crock-Pot Artisan Oval Enameled Cast Iron Dutch Oven, 7-Quart, Slate Gray
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful pot at a great price!', 'author': 'Stan', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The pot is beautiful. I have a cast iron but this is my first ceramic cast. title: Cuisinart Chef's Classic Enameled Cast Iron 7-Quart Round Covered Casserole, Cardinal Red
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect, especially for the price', 'author': 'Michael L', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Replaced a years-old higher end brand that had npbecome stained and chipped. So far this one seems solid, durable, easy to clean, and distributes heat well. Plus it looks great!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 19, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Enjoy Dutch Oven cooking at a fraction of the cost of Le Creuset', 'author': 'Marc', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This has been a value pick by America's Test Kitchen for some time now, and it's not hard to see why. This really is just as good as my Le Creuset. The LC is known for durability, and I am being extremely careful with this Cuisinart so that I don't chip the enamel, but so far, so good. The only drawback, and this would be true for any brand, is that it's heavy! The tradeoff is that you get even heating, as well as amazing heat retention. Dutch Ovens are fun, and you don't have to spend a fortune on one, but if you're going to spend money, get one that's durable. This Cuisinart fits the bill!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent value', 'author': 'Rsw', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This is the third enameled iron pan I've purchased, and the combination of functionality, weight and price are very hard to beat. The two other enameled pans I compare in this review are Le Creuset and Lodge.I really like cooking on enamel iron pans because of durability, ease of cleaning, and not having to worry about the chemicals in non-stick pans. But to prevent sticking, one should use lower flames than one might be used to with other kinds of pans. Iron retains heat and gets hotter than other types of pans, which causes burning and sticking. And one must coat with oil after heating and before putting the food in the pan.Shape - The Cuisinart bottom is perfectly flat, whereas the center of the Lodge pan is slightly raised (imagine a dome that has been almost completely flattened, but is not perfectly flat). Consequently, the Cuisinart is better than the Lodge for cooking omelettes because eggs gravitate to the perimeter of the Lodge and might not cook evenly.Shape - The Cuisinart bottom intersects the wall of the pan at an angle. The same is true for the Lodge. In contrast, the Le Creuset bottom rises gradually upwards to form the wall, so food won't get caught at the edge of the Le Creuset. Depending on your cooking technique, you might prefer one shape over the other.Weight-wise, the Cuisinart and Le Creuset are manageable, and the Lodge is very heavy (it is a workout to wash and dry).Durability - the enamel is chipping on the handle of the Lodge, but not on the cooking surfaces, where it matters most. So it's unsightly, but it does not affect functionality. There is no chipping with the other pans.Price - the Cuisinart and the Lodge were each about a third the price of the Le Creuset.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 29, 2012', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great little Dutch oven', 'author': 'Rick Bledsoe', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I got this in a 3 quart size because my others were just too big for some tasks. I‚Äôve used it a few times now and it works great with no complaints. Easy cleanup.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 2, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great Dutch oven', 'author': 'Danielle M.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Not my first one and won‚Äôt be my last. These are well made look good and cook your food perfectly. Kitchen staple.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Enameled?', 'author': 'sue h.', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Bought this frying pan because we like to cook on cast iron. I thought the description said enameled inside and out. It doesn't seem to be enameled on the inside. Things do stick to it, especially eggs. It is mostly easy to clean though. It does heat evenly. Not sure if I would buy another one.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Easy to clean!', 'author': 'CAH', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I like how there is even heating and the large size.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 1, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars America's Test Kitchen Recommended", 'author': 'gittinrdunuall', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I purchased because America's Test Kitchen recommended this Dutch oven. title: Lodge 7 Quart Enameled Cast Iron Dutch Oven with Lid ‚Äì Dual Handles ‚Äì Oven Safe up to 500¬∞ F or on Stovetop - Use to Marinate, Cook, Bake, Refrigerate and Serve ‚Äì Red
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect Size for Side Dishes', 'author': 'I_Yam_Who_I_Yam', 'rating': 5, 'content': "It's just the two of us so... When my non-stick cookware died a long and painful death (may it rest in pieces), we needed to replace it, and the sticking point for us was a small enough pan to throw a can of corn in to heat it up for dinner. We always nuked our veggies, but they didn't stay warm for a long enough time to matter. Enter this little gem: everything stays nice and hot on the table as long as you replace the lid after serving from it. It's the perfect size for two people, and maybe up to four folks if using two cans.We have several pieces of non-coated cast iron, and I LOVE the way they perform, so I took a deep breath and ordered several Enameled Cast Iron pieces.1. This is perfect for oven-to-table use because it's nice-looking as well as tough as nails.2. The heat retention is fantastic; everything stays hot while you're eating.3. The heat distribution while cooking is the best I've seen: it caramelizes onions and browns meat evenly and far more rapidly than my non-stick pans and crates a beautiful fond on the bottom which is the cook's ideal result4. The cleanup is quick and easy, a nylon scrub pad (do NOT use anything that can scratch the surface such as Brillo or cleansers) is all that's needed. I don't put these in a dishwasher, per the manufacturer's recommendation to hand wash.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 30, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great dutch oven that cleans up easily', 'author': 'Michelle G.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Bought this dutch oven for chicken and dumplings. Very first time using it, i overflowed it. I thought it would be a scrub job, nope, cleaned up easily. It keepa food super hot when taking a dish elsewhere.However, being cast iron it is heavy.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 15, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this dutch oven', 'author': 'Janet J.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I love this dutch oven so much that I bought a second one since the first was always in use. I have two of the much more expensive enameled pots but I wind up always using the Lodge pots. I love the size and shape and the price was excellent', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 13, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Hard to find size', 'author': 'Fiddlesticks!', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I use my wood stove to cook on...it's so easy and practical. These enameled cast iron dutch ovens are invaluable for cooking virtually anything on the wood stove, an induction cook top, gas, and electric radiant cook top. On warmer days when we don't have the wood stove going, I use this on the glass cook top on low as a slow cooker or oven.This is a very hard-to-get size. Basically, only Lodge and Le Creuset make this size. For the price, this is definitely the logical choice. I own quite a bit of enameled cast iron from various brands and have never had problems with the Lodge pieces. I can't understand why anyone would spring for several hundred dollars when the same thing is so much more affordable from Lodge. The only improvement is I wish Lodge used other colors in this size. That's what Le Creuset has over other manufacturers. Greens? Yellows? Oranges? Purples? The jewel tones would be so pretty sitting out on an exposed shelf in the kitchen.As far as the Lodge dutch oven, all the things that make a difference are there:-the bottom is flat, not rough so it won't scratch the glass cook top-the bottom of the dutch oven has a large ratio of cook surface for the volume (as opposed to the cute but illogical apple oven that Lodge makes) so the heating is faster-the bottom is flat, not concave, for more even heating (a concave bottom is useless, even harmful, on glass cook tops)-the lid sits snugly on the oven and doesn't rock so steam doesn't escape during cooking with the food drying out-handles are sufficient for grasping-the enameled surface allows me to cook more acidic foods, like tomato bases, and white foods, like rice or quinoa, without staining the food-the size is just right for soup for two, rice, reheating leftovers, two cans of corn, etc.It's heavy, of course. You hope it's heavy because it's not iron if it isn't. Iron IS heavy - check the periodic table of elements. It'll save that trip to the gym for the reps on the arms.Meanwhile, remember that the enamel is basically glass which shatters if there is a quick change in temperature. The iron and enamel expand and contract at different rates so warm it with warm water before putting it on a very hot surface, like a hot stove, if you don't want small cracks in the surface. If the inside stains, it's from a strongly colored food entering the small fissures that you created when changing the temperature too quickly. I've recently discovered a great cleaner for these pots - the Kohler cast iron sink cleaner works miracles on the stains in these pots!! Amazing!After removing all of the contents, initially soak it with water that is a similar temperature. ALL enameled cast iron needs this precaution, the brand doesn't matter. But, with its versatility and length of life, it's worth it!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 12, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars Can't go wrong with Lodge", 'author': 'Alisa Jerauld', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Love the sturdy quality of Lodge pans. The color is beautiful and was a great gift for family member', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 10, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Chips easily but cooks well', 'author': 'Denise L.', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I had to return the first one because it arrived chipped. I was so disappointed. Then the next one arrived and the cover does not fit as securely as if should but I kept it. After I used it the first time there was a chip in the handle. I don‚Äôt know how this happened because I‚Äôve been so careful and carefully hand washed it. But the reviews said that. It cooks really well though. I loved using it. I‚Äôve used it twice. Once for a Dutch oven lasagne and second for a beef roast. The pot is really heavy so it is difficult to get into the oven if you have the oven under the stove. If I could afford the le creuset I would have those instead.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 31, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Sturdy, durable cast iron.', 'author': 'Aaliyah', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Another fantastic product from Lodge, this one is the perfect size to bake a loaf of bread.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Lodge Cast Iron has my heart!', 'author': 'Jessica Westerholm', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The quality of the Lodge cast iron products that I have purchased cannot be beat! I have purchased one Lodge cast iron piece for myself (though I want more soon) and two as gifts. Between my cast iron piece and the other two gift pieces they have made the best roasts, soups, tomato sauce, salsa, goulashes and so much more! These pieces are heavy (duty), durable, easy to clean, and it sounds weird to say about a piece of cookware, but BEAUTIFUL! Would buy again and again and again! Plan to continue building my collection!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 26, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love it', 'author': 'TonyaU', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I love this thing you can bake bread in it casseroles use it on the stove top. It‚Äôs perfect it‚Äôs sturdy. I love lodge products.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 18, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Dutch Oven', 'author': 'Joyce', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I received it one day last week. The next day I made one of the best pot roasts I‚Äôve ever made. My budget doesn‚Äôt afford me a Le Cruset. This Lodge did not disappoint.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 8, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Scanpan Classic 6.5 Quart Covered Dutch Oven
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Exactly what you expect.', 'author': 'James Wakeley', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Perfect size for winter cooking, and super easy to clean. Made well, of high-quality material.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Scanpan is my all-time favorite', 'author': 'Faith', 'rating': 5, 'content': "First, there is a discrepancy in the reviews about the size of the 4-qt pan. The box says 5.25qts (now the smallest Dutch oven style Scanpan makes but out of stock on their website) but the pot itself that I ordered directly from Amazon is 4qts. I filled it with water and it's 4 qts to within an inch of the top.I have some Scanpan cookware that I have had for years. Frying pans lasted at least five years - pans we used every day. But it was time to replace the big stock pot and the 3.5-qt Dutch oven. The 3.5qt with the double handles is no longer made, so I looked for a replacement and did a lot of research on non-stick cookware. Even though I have a great stainless set, I'm not making my holiday cranberry sauce in anything but non-stick.Scanpan still gets the highest marks for durability in reviews, and now with improved coatings. Most important, it's quality cookware. I've had it with my husband coming home with pans from the junk closeout stores that last a month, especially when he uses high heat and metal utensils. I told him - no more new pans for you until you mend your ways, and he has.I will say that it's probably not quite as hefty as the pans I bought 15 years ago, but still very well made and sturdy. I tested its heat distribution: perfectly even bubbles when boiling water. No hot or cold spots anywhere. It also retains heat extremely well. Even my husband noticed that he had to turn down the heat after it was completely heated. My husband's chili was beautifully evenly cooked. And everything slides right out. I've hidden all the metal utensils and I make sure he doesn't go over medium heat. No matter what any non-stick cookware manufacturers tell you, NO metal, NO heat over medium, and hand wash. These are the keys to long lasting non-stick cookware.We originally bought our Scanpan cookware at a really true closeout store, and I didn't even know it was still sold in America. Of course, I can't attest if it will last over a decade like my original Scanpan cookware. If I have any issues, I will certainly edit my review.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 19, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome brand', 'author': 'graciela amaya', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I love this pan, it‚Äôs excellent to cook well the food and cleaning easily. Great invest', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 27, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Scanpan rocks!', 'author': 'jocerana', 'rating': 5, 'content': "After reading ratings in Consumer Reports, I gave my old set to my niece when she got her first apartment and carefully choose Scanpan classic pots and pans to make a small but complete set as they are a little pricey. Amazon's prices were as inexpensive as I found. I love them! They cook evenly and clean up so easily it's almost ridiculous.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2013', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Not as described', 'author': 'jp777', 'rating': 3, 'content': 'This is a 6.5 liter (7 quart) pot not a 6.5 quart, clearly stated on the box. Very disappointed I did not get a 6.5 quart. Returned.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States April 13, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great pot; beware handle on lid; highly recommend', 'author': '–êmazon\xa0Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Love this pot and use it once a week. Only word of caution, the screw holding the handle onto the lid loosens over time and can come off. It dropped off on my husband and shattered on our tile floor. Fortunately, we had another one. Just be aware and check each time you use.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 25, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A very good pan', 'author': 'Jo Ann Hakola', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Cooks well and is easy to clean.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 28, 2019', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '1.0 out of 5 stars Interior chips', 'author': 'Linda Dazey', 'rating': 1, 'content': 'Have used this 4 times and the finish is chipping on interior. There is no free return shipping, so get ready to pay a high price just to return and be sent another one that will probably do the same thing. THUMBS DOWN!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 15, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars different color', 'author': 'Karyn W', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I do like my Scanpans, so far. I haven\'t had them long, so don\'t know how well they\'ll last.What annoys me about this pot is that, while my other two Scanpan Classic pieces are a dark gray, this one is black. Not terribly important, I know, but I did want a matching set.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 16, 2018', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Cleaning ease', 'author': 'pseudandry', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'After years and years of using our old scanpan, and not saving the receipt for its warranty, we both this new one. Not as sturdy(?), hefty(?), substantial (?) as the older models, but still easy to clean and good heat distribution.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 12, 2020', 'is_verified': True}]

reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Heavy-duty great quality and beautiful too!', 'author': 'mysterywriter', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This Dutch oven is a beautiful, rich red color that I absolutely love (my photo does not do it justice). Since it is cast iron underneath the enamel coating you do have to be careful in two ways. One, you don‚Äôt want to scratch the coating and two, if you drop this pot it could definitely break other dishes. Also it says to be careful not to shock it with abrupt temperature changes. Since I am using this for larger cooking items like stews for in the oven, I got the 7.5 QT oval size, but if you are cooking for only 1 or 2 people or not making large quantities I think the smaller round version would fit better on the cooktop and be easier to handle because it would have a smaller size and weight. I couldn‚Äôt justify the expense, and most of the other brands either didn‚Äôt fit my style, or had a knob I knew I would have to replace for use in the oven‚Ä¶ then I saw this one.The color, quality, pattern and lack of a brand on the top really set it apart from the other off brands available. The turquoise color and lid design match our eclectic Southwestern decor seamlessly. The price was perfect for what I‚Äôm willing to spend right now. So even with my lack of knowledge on the Spice brand- the small 20+ amount of 5 star reviews convinced me this was a purchase I could take a risk on.Boy does this baby cook! I have an Always Pan and an Instant Pot that I do most of my cooking in- the real downside is that neither of those can go in the oven. Even with the crisp attachment on the instant pot- I never get that dreamy bubbling crust I crave from cheesy casserole dishes- and I really hate using multiple pots and pans for 1 meal especially on a weeknight. This is the solution! I can do EVERYTHING in this pot and then put it in the oven. The first thing I made was a chicken broccoli bake- and even though my photo isn‚Äôt the prettiest to look at- it was TASTY! Evenly cooked all the way through, with a beautiful cheesy crust. Yum! Etc!Would highly recommend to anyone! The quality is exceptional and the value for money is on point!***UPDATED AFTER USE OVER A MONTH OR 2***This Dutch oven has been an every other day use item since I got it. I do love it- the food is phenomenal. However the paint is starting to wear and chip on the outside. It doesn‚Äôt really bother me. The product still performs. I won‚Äôt change the star on it unless the inner white enamel starts to chip.I‚Äôm very pleased with food that has come out of it- just did a 4 lb pork shoulder inside on a weekday! I still leave it on the stove- even with the chips. It hasn‚Äôt been dropped or washed any harder than a heavy cast iron pan would be. I consider myself to be pretty strong in terms of holding it up- but haven‚Äôt had to really scrub it.I bought the turquoise one- which chipped maybe a month or 2 after I bought it.I would still recommend this product‚Ä¶ just might not buy it for someone else‚Ä¶ or pass it down. title: Herogo 6 Quart Enameled Cast Iron Dutch Oven with Lid and Silicone Trivet Mat, Round Dutch Oven Pot Blue with Dual Handles for Bread Baking Stewing Roasting Various Stoves & Oven Safe
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent 6 qt Dutch Oven at a bargain price', 'author': 'Bonz4248', 'rating': 5, 'content': "First of all this Dutch Over came beautiful packaged, it was wrapped completely in foam to absolutely insure there would be no damage in shipping. The lid was surrounded in cardboard so it could not contact the pot and cause chipping or other damage.Upon removing the Dutch Oven and lid I was immediately impressed with the beauty and flawlessness of the enamel finish. The handles are large and easy to use, everything about the appearance and condition of the set was great.I've now used it to cook on my stove, in my oven, and on an induction heating plate and it worked well on all. The heat distribution was excellent and the food was delicious. The cleanup was easy as well.This product arrives with a set of very useful instructions and pointers that is well written by an obviouly native english speaking individual.I also have a 7¬Ω qt Le Cruset Dutch Oven and in the short run this one seems to hold it's own against it. I know Le Cruset items are supposed to last forever, and at this point I can't vouch for this one in the same way. However for such a great price this one is really a bargain and in my hands I can't tell much difference in the performance of either oven.
