I will be getting more.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 21, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars great for roasting veggies', 'author': 'HJ', 'rating': 5, 'content': "bought this to better roast my veggies. it works great for that. but it is super heavy...so be prepared for that. cleans up well but you can't avoid some marks on a white pan", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 10, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nonstick Is a Relative Concept', 'author': 'A', 'rating': 4, 'content': "First, the specifics:The color of this pan is quite a bit darker than the pictures. It is not turquoise. It's teal. It exactly matches a tramontina dutch oven I bought a few years ago. Exactly. (That pot is holding up great, btw.) First use was for tetrazzini - cooked evenly, cleaned fairly easily by boiling vinegar and water in it and letting it soak until the water cooled, and still looks new.Now the general stuff: Enameled cast iron is not nonstick in the way that thermalon is or the way that teflon is. But as long as it isn't enameled with lead (which is why I usually buy expensive stuff), it is more nonstick than bare stainless steel. It's about the same as well-seasoned cast iron. Unless it's the rough gray enamel, in which case, it's not nonstick at all.This is a surprisingly inexpensive name brand lasagna pan. It's the white smooth enamel. It's not going to release everything or clean up with a quick sponge wipe. Best practice is to soak and wipe. Don't use harsh cleansers or scrubbers. Other best practice is try not to burn the &*&* out of it.It will cook evenly and efficiently. It won't warp for anything. It may chip -> even the more expensive pans will. But again, as long as you've bought something well sourced, it won't hurt you. Rust won't hurt you, either. It's iron. Wash it off. Dry it thoroughly.It may stain. This also won't hurt you. The super expensive brands also chip and stain. When you've paid a few hundred bucks for one of them? Now that will hurt you.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2020', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great', 'author': 'Stephanie Voss', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I truly love this baking dish üòç üòçüòçüòçüòç', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Product fit and finish look great. Only problem it‚Äôs the handles get very hot', 'author': 'Ace', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Great pan. Love it', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 17, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Throw away your cast iron Dutch oven', 'author': 'Anthony F', 'rating': 5, 'content': "You will have to return to the gym to get those arm muscles, because those (high-priced) cast iron Dutch ovens are now obsolete. Now, maybe you're a great cook, or at least like to cook. Not me; in fact, I wish I could microwave everything. But I found with a little patience, baking in the oven was far better for some types of food. So out would come the (very fake) 5-quart Le Creuset until one day, I forgot which came first - heat the oven and then put the pot in or let the pot heat up with the oven (and let's not mention that I have a pizza stone in there). Sure enough, I hear a 'pow' as the pot cracks in half. Thank goodness, I wasn't cooking anything liquid. Eventually, I broke down and went shopping to replace the pot. At Home Goods of course, where I had purchased the first one for less than fifty bucks. They had nothing. Hmm, I researched the brand and manufacturer (generic, Chinese). I start looking through anything that Amazon had (I didn't know what the thing was called so I started with 'stoneware' - don't ask why). 3 days later, and ready for bed, I see around $300 for the real Le Creuset, anywhere from $100-$200 for other brands, and - hey, wait, around $50 for an Amazon Basics? Hmm, maybe I should, but I am always afraid of something that is so much cheaper. Cast iron, cast iron, it has to be non-stick cast iron (I have no idea if that's right, all I knew about the previous pot was, well, nothing - it cracked in half and didn't look like cast iron inside). I am about to give up when I see Granitestone. Oh, what a scam. But I start to read the reviews and I read more and research more and heck, $60 for a 5-quart aluminum pot. It can't be any good, but after three days I was punch drunk for scanning cookware (I haven't touched alcohol for over a dozen years but I remember the feeling!). I'm very frugal (OK, cheap) and was sure I was wasting good money but I ordered it (6 very different colors to choose from but I thought the blue looked attractive). It arrived. It sat for a week, while I pondered simply returning it. So light, was there even anything in the box? It gets unpacked - and sits outside the box for another week. By now, you're thinking, is he ever going to tell us if he liked the pot? Well, yes, I did like the pot. I love the pot! (Eh, let's not get carried away, I still don't like to cook.) It is incredibly lightweight but beautifully crafted. I have now made almost a dozen different things in it. About a quarter of them, I burnt to a crisp. Not the pot's fault. It turns out that 45 minutes in a 350 degree oven will burn some things to a crisp. But shockingly enough, not reduced to dust or, worse, to be glued to the pot and destroying the non-stick surface. If you like toasted, crispy food, you're in luck - dinner is saved. For you; don't serve your guests burnt food. But the foods were edible and the pot cleaned with one swipe of a sponge or even a paper towel. Everything about the experience has been positive, right down to the packaging and the advertising copy. I trusted the many positive reviews here on Amazon and I was not disappointed. I think you will feel the same way. I must add that this is the longest of the (very few) reviews I have submitted to Amazon. I'm a retired minister, with little or no expertise in cooking. But I know good when I see it. Try it. You'll like it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 23, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Dutch oven gets the job done!', 'author': 'Boyd', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I like that this pan is not heavy, it's nonstick (easy clean up) and it can go from stove top to oven (500 degrees) with no problem. Haven't used it in the oven yet but I really like that especially with the lid on. So far I am very pleased with this dutch oven. üòÄ", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 22, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great for making my artisan bread.', 'author': 'Audrey C.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I needed a Dutch oven to make artisan bread but did not want the weight of a cast iron one. title: Lodge Camp Dutch Oven Lid Lifter. Black 9 MM Bar Stock for Lifting and Carrying Dutch Ovens. (Black Finish)
reviews: [{'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars It's a good product.", 'author': 'Rob Gurganus', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is a well-made and handy product. Great for its intended purpose of lifting hot lids off pots.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars It works as intended.', 'author': 'Glenn Cox', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I cooked two peach cobblers, and each time I uses device to lift the lid on my Dutch oven. It worked well at doing what it was supposed to do. But I might buy a little longer one if I purchased again. This one is pretty short, so your hand is close to briquettes that rest on the lid of the Dutch oven. Another 5 inches in length would be nice.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 31, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Indispensable tool for cooking outdoors with cast iron Dutch ovens', 'author': 'Chris S.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This odd looking thing is superbly designed to lift up the top of a Dutch oven from a campfire and let you check inside without spilling coals and ashes into your food from on top of the lid being lifted. Strong and sturdy, with leverage both for pulling up and for keeping the lid controlled and horizontal while lifted. Rarely have I ever found such an immensely practical tool for a reasonable investment. Can probably be passed down to your children along with your cast iron Dutch ovens.P.S. Before you lift your lid, give some thought to where you'll set it down while going back to stir your food or whatever. You need to keep it fairly level, so that ashes and coals don't spill, and you'll need a pretty clean surface, because the underside of the lid is going to go back on top of your food when you return the lid to your oven. Or else you need to be able to hold the lid lifter and lid level and straight in one hand while stirring with the other!P.P.S. Important: if you're hanging the oven by the bail/handle over the fire, you'll need to take the oven off the fire first and set it down so that you can let the bail fall to the side. The lid can't really be lifted off the top without slanting it sideways to extract it and thus spilling ashes all over the pan's contents if the bail is vertical.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 27, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Works great with lodge dutch oven', 'author': 'Don', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Looks great and made well', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 5, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Jack of alll Trades / Best overall Performer', 'author': 'Brian J. F.', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I have three lifters to compare. They are the traditional styled Lodge A5 Camp Dutch Oven Lid Lifter, this Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid Lifter, and the Camp Chef Professional Dutch Oven Lid Lifter (Black, 9-Inch). Here is my unbiased opinion of all three.Lodge A5 Camp Dutch Oven Lid LifterPros:This is a multi-purpose item and it surprisingly has the best finish & has the least sloppily welded junctions of all three lifters.I say this is a multi-purpose item because the two deluxe lifters are pretty much dedicated dutch oven table / charcoal cooking items. If you are cooking over a campfire I would go with the A5 because it can be used as a fire poker, and a coal rake as well as a lid lifter.The A5 lifter is just as good as the Camp Chef when it comes to carrying a dutch oven by the bail handle over long distances because of the T-handle portion that is welded to the handle. The Deluxe Lodge A5DLL lifter is slightly worse because of the odd downward slope of the handle.Cons:The A5 does not have a cushioned handle like the other two.There is more of a learning curve as far as balancing the lid is concerned.... But not as drastic as other reviewers would lead you to believe unless you are truly an uncoordinated klutz. Yes, the deluxe lifters are both more stable when it comes to controlling the lid, but as of right now, the only major thing I can do with the other lifters that I cannot do with the traditional A5 is grab the lid and turn it completely upside down. Unless you are a tricked out dutch oven stunt cooking artist, then there is really no need to do this. I'm still able to use the A5 to tilt the lid to either side to knock the ashes off and whatever else I need to do while cooking and transporting (by the bail handle) the ovens. The point, I am trying to make is that the A5 is not as bad as people try to make it out to be.Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid LifterPros:This one has the best length for ground cooking. That is about the only good advantage that this one has over the rest of them, however, if you plan on doing deep bean hole type cooking, then I would go with the Camp Chef Professional Dutch Oven Lid Lifter, 22-Inch (which I do not own, but looks identical to the 9-inch which I do own).Cons:The finish on this model is the worst of the three. It is almost as if they baked on the finish and then tried to weld it together after the fact... as opposed to the Camp Chef which looks like it was welded first... then baked on the finished (which is how I would expect the process to be done). Then inner bar of the A5DLL Deluxe wiggles and turns inside the outer sleeve much more so than the Camp Chef, which is very annoying.I am not sure I am all that sold on the downward slope of the A5DLL handle as opposed to the straight, parallel handle configuration of the Camp Chef.To me, this is the worst lifter... and it cost the most. Looks like I paid more for the Lodge name, rather than any added or superior benefits over the Camp Chef version. However it's not really something that I would waste time trying to return through the mail because the advantages of the Camp Chef version over this one are minimal. If I had to do it all over again, knowing what I know now, I would probably have purchased the 14-inch Camp Chef version over the A5DLL, but then I would be giving up 2 inches in length which is better for ground cooking as opposed to table cooking.Camp Chef Professional Dutch oven Lid Lifter (Black, 9-Inch)Pros:This one is the best for dutch oven table cooking because of its length. It keeps you from having the move the ovens around on the table in an awkward position because the length is just right.The handle on the Camp Chef has more of a solid feel than the Lodge Deluxe A5DLL version. The parallel bar configuration works the best for me.The weld junctions on the Camp Chef are better and it has a slightly more beefier construction than the Lodge Deluxe A5DLL. However, the lodge A5 has the best welds (read: more durability) of all three lifters that I own.Cons:The only con I can see at this point is that the metal is exposed under the outer sleeve of the t-handle (I assume to make it slide better inside the sleeve) on the Camp Chef. There could be a rusting issue somewhere down the line... then again maybe not because it looks like that part is galvanized. Only time will tell. There really is no need for this portion to be unfinished, because part of the bar that slides within the tube is finished and it does not hinder the way the bar functions at all.Final thoughts:Overall I like the traditional A5 the best but that is just my personal preference because of its multi-functional versatility. It's just a jack of all trades. I can do almost everything the deluxe lifters can do, plus I can use it as a fire poker and a coal raker.If you are cooking over a campfire, go with the A-5. If your cooking is limited only to cooking on a dutch oven table, then I would go with the 9-inch Camp Chef lifter. If you are ground or bean-hole cooking then I would take a long look at both the Camp Chef 14-inch and 22-inch lid lifters before deciding to buy the Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid Lifter.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 28, 2013', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great useful tool for safety; excellent condition; great packaging', 'author': 'Take And Read', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The Lodge Camp Dutch Oven Lifter came in excellent condition. It was shipped in a box within a box! Inside the inner box, super care was taken to protect your Dutch Oven Lifter during shipping. All the edges on the tool were EACH wrapped with a protective covering! The Lifter is a great safety item for protecting the cook from burns when lifting hot lids from cast iron pots. Very useful tool to have at hand.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Will last a lifetime.', 'author': 'ST', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Built well and surdy.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 17, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Multiple use', 'author': 'Carol', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'It is great to lift the lid off and also stoking the fire. Happy I bought it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 30, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars no glove needed', 'author': 'Scott S', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'if you have a Dutch oven you need one of these.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 22, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars A little short', 'author': 'Rob T', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Well built holds the lid well but it would be nice if it was a bit longer to keep your hands further from the heat.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 26, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Dutch Oven Pot Lid Holder - Convenient Kitchen Accessory for Dutch Ovens and Cast Iron Skillets - Keep Your Lids Handy (an odd one)
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars steady and nice dutch lid holder', 'author': 'Frank Tai', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Recently bought a dutch oven but was frustrated no place to put the lid. this is a nice holder perfectly made and can hold the lid steadily', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 26, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '2.0 out of 5 stars Good in concept', 'author': 'ATXBuyer', 'rating': 2, 'content': "I wanted to like this tool so much, because I have a lot of enameled cast iron pots. In concept, it's great, but in practice, it only works on one of my pots. I have some pots with lids that are incompatible which I knew, but the ones that are compatible still didn't work. That's because the other thing that has to fit is the opening of the pot handle. This device is too big for most pot handles except for my very largest oval Staub pot. I tried it on my 5qt, 7qt, large saute, and 10qt.It's a solid piece of wood (though it arrived with a chip) and sturdy enough to hold the large, heavy lid. However, it was very awkward figuring out how to lift the heavy, hot lid and slip it on the lid holder without burning your hand. It naturally tilts the lid towards the pot which helps drip condensation back into the pot.The one kind of nice thing is that it fits perfectly in my large, oval Staub which is the only one it fits, so I can just store it in there for when I use the large pot.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 1, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars quality product. works great if it fits your pots lids and/or handles.', 'author': 'Kurt', 'rating': 5, 'content': "i love this thing. it solidly built and fits a niche. it only works with some of my pots, but that's more than what I had before. It works for my staub 6.25 qt round dutch oven and my 7 qt oval dutch oven (for the oval oven you have to put the lid horizontally and not vertically). It does not work with my le creuset 5 qt round dutch oven (the lid knob does not fit, it does fit in the pot handles). it does not work with my cuisinart 7qt chef's classic enameled cast iron dutch oven. it fits in the handles, but the lid knob does not fit. You can also use this with regular stock pots as well. You can fit/hang the lid handle inside the knob carrier. It works with my all clad 6 qt and 12 qt stock/soup pots, but not my 5qt one (it's too big for the pot handles). It works with my cuisinart multiclad pro 8 qt stock pot as well. This has a definite spot in my kitchen as it will free up counter space for the lids of these pots. love it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 2, 2023', 'is_verified': False}]

reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Works Well', 'author': 'Alan Nelson', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'What can I say, this is the best cleaner to remove stains from Le Creuset pots. Been using for years to keep pots looking like new.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Works great', 'author': 'YK', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Little amount works the magic.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I Was Surprised', 'author': 'MG Fan', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This cleaner is not inexpensive and honestly I thought I would be sending it back, BUT, it really worked. I just recently bought another LC dutch oven and wanted to be sure to keep it looking like new, as much as possible. On a whim, I used this cleaner on my several years old dutch oven that was showing a bit of wear and it cleaned it like new without much elbow grease. I was surprised and very impressed. I would definitely recommend this product. It does not require a lot of cleaner to remove stains so it should last you for a while.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Product great but packaging insufficient', 'author': 'msilvey', 'rating': 4, 'content': "There was a problem with the packaging of the LeCreuset cleaner. When it arrived I noticed a chemical smell coming from the package -- a bubble wrap manilla envelope -- inadequate for the long trip across the country. During shipment the cap on the bottle broke and cleaner leaked throughout the package, creating a real mess. I'm not asking for a replacement but for you to inform the seller this cleaner needs to be more thoroughly wrapped in a box for shipment. I can use the contents but will store the bottle in a sealed plastic bag. The cleaner works great on my LeCreuset cookware.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 3, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Cleans very well', 'author': 'AGS58', 'rating': 5, 'content': "We had some residue from cooking in our new Le Creuset enameled pot. I didn't want to scratch the finish so tried this recommended cleaner. The sticky residue came off immediately. Works well without scratching. The cookware looks as good as new.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 7, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars i never got my refund and it did not work', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'never got my refund', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I was skeptical, but No More', 'author': 'JC-Franklin', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I had debated about my need for this cleaner when I got a LeCreuset Dutch oven for Christmas. I read the reviews that some just used Dawn dishwashing liquid. I was doing the same with good results, but I went ahead and ordered this cleaner along with the recommended scrubber. I put it under the sink and didn‚Äôt use it because Dawn was working well. Then, after making a beef stew, and cooking it for a few hours, slowly, there was a stubborn stain on the bottom that I couldn‚Äôt get off with the Dawn, even using the LeCreuset scrubber. So I put a bit of this cleaner on it and the stain came right off!Considering that I‚Äôll only use this product occasionally, and not as my main cleaner, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs worth the price, and should last a good while.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Not quite what I had hoped for', 'author': 'S. West', 'rating': 3, 'content': "I've been trying to remove stains from my Le Creuset for years. I've tried Bar Keeper's Friend and several homemade mixtures that include rubbing alcohol, baking soda, salt...you name it. Nothing has taken off the dark spots on the exterior of the pots. This product took a little bit off. It strikes me as a product for brand-new Le Creuset, not stained cookware. It was pretty expensive for what it ultimately accomplished.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 20, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars It does work...', 'author': 'Rick Medugno', 'rating': 4, 'content': "somewhat on my expensive Le Creuset pans. Would not recommend using it regularly. It would probably damage the enamel over time. The 3 tablespoons of bleach to 1 quart of water method, soak for 2 to 3 hours, this will clean 95% of the enamel stains. This Le Creuset cleaner will work for removing the other 5%. So it's worth having around.Make sure you always cook at Medium of lower and you won't burn the pans in first place. Cast Iron Enamel gets super hot, so high heat is never needed.Also the outside of these pans can be cleaned with basic oven cleaner spray. But again, I would not recommend using it regularly either. If you cook properly, soap and hot water should work most of the time!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Sample should come with the cookware', 'author': 'KulaBestie', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I wish I'd known about this product when I purchased my enameled cookware. If I had, I wouldn't be having to work so hard with this product to get my old pans back into shape. That being said, it seems to be working.It just takes a lot of elbow grease & a brush to use this cleaner despite the bottle saying you just need a damp cloth or sponge for it.Also, there are no instructions to use gloves with this, but I think going forward I will. After using it bare-handed for a few hours on some cookware, I started feeling a little ill.Will keep at it. A little seems to go a long way. And letting it sit on deeper stains for a while seems to help make scrubbing through old layers a little easier. But, it will take me several applications & a lot of work to get through this.Hot tip Le Creuset: Include a bonus little sample bottle with your cookware sales so folks know it exists AND will buy it again in bigger volumes later!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 19, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

Unlike other lifters you can grab the lid and really have good control of your dutch oven.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 25, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I broke up with my other lid lifter for you, Lodge Deluxe', 'author': "Outdoorsy Boy's Mom", 'rating': 5, 'content': 'My plain old traditional lid lifter is pissed. It has served me on quite a few campouts but has recently been upstaged by this Lodge Deluxe lid lifter. At this week\'s campfire cooking event this new deluxe lid lifter frequently went "missing" as it was happily used by others who pitched their plain lid lifters off into the grass in favor of mine. I\'m pretty sure the old lid lifters conspired to retaliate because they tripped us up constantly as they seemed to be everywhere we stepped and their all-black bodies were impossible to spot in the dark. The bright yellow handles on this deluxe lid lifter made it easy to locate in the flickering firelight, especially with it\'s long, leggy shape that free-stands on its own. At the end of the night the deluxe model held on firmly as I swung my dutch oven lid completely upside down to return the coals on top of it to the fire, obviously sparking jealousy from the older lid lifters who previously had so much fun dropping the lid on my toe when I attempted such a move. Those cantankerous old lid lifters have all been demoted to fire log pokes and marshmallow roasters. Break up with your old lid lifter and upgrade to a real tool who knows how to treat you right!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect birthday gift for my outdoor chef', 'author': 'Kathe', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Campfire and woodstove cooking with cast iron cookware.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Slightly Worse than the Camp Chef verson plus it costs more', 'author': 'Brian J. F.', 'rating': 3, 'content': "I have three lifters to compare. They are the traditional styled Lodge A5 Camp Dutch Oven Lid Lifter, this Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid Lifter, and the Camp Chef Professional Dutch Oven Lid Lifter (Black, 9-Inch). Here is my unbiased opinion of all three.Lodge A5 Camp Dutch Oven Lid LifterPros:This is a multi-purpose item and it surprisingly has the best finish & has the least sloppily welded junctions of all three lifters.I say this is a multi-purpose item because the two deluxe lifters are pretty much dedicated dutch oven table / charcoal cooking items. If you are cooking over a campfire I would go with the A5 because it can be used as a fire poker, and a coal rake as well as a lid lifter.The A5 lifter is just as good as the Camp Chef when it comes to carrying a dutch oven by the bail handle over long distances because of the T-handle portion that is welded to the handle. The Deluxe Lodge A5DLL lifter is slightly worse because of the odd downward slope of the handle.Cons:The A5 does not have a cushioned handle like the other two.There is more of a learning curve as far as balancing the lid is concerned.... But not as drastic as other reviewers would lead you to believe unless you are truly an uncoordinated klutz. Yes, the deluxe lifters are both more stable when it comes to controlling the lid, but as of right now, the only major thing I can do with the other lifters that I cannot do with the traditional A5 is grab the lid and turn it completely upside down. Unless you are a tricked out dutch oven stunt cooking artist, then there is really no need to do this. I'm still able to use the A5 to tilt the lid to either side to knock the ashes off and whatever else I need to do while cooking and transporting (by the bail handle) the ovens. The point, I am trying to make is that the A5 is not as bad as people try to make it out to be.Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid LifterPros:This one has the best length for ground cooking. That is about the only good advantage that this one has over the rest of them, however, if you plan on doing deep bean hole type cooking, then I would go with the Camp Chef Professional Dutch Oven Lid Lifter, 22-Inch (which I do not own, but looks identical to the 9-inch which I do own).Cons:The finish on this model is the worst of the three. It is almost as if they baked on the finish and then tried to weld it together after the fact... as opposed to the Camp Chef which looks like it was welded first... then baked on the finished (which is how I would expect the process to be done). Then inner bar of the A5DLL Deluxe wiggles and turns inside the outer sleeve much more so than the Camp Chef, which is very annoying.I am not sure I am all that sold on the downward slope of the A5DLL handle as opposed to the straight, parallel handle configuration of the Camp Chef.To me, this is the worst lifter... and it cost the most. Looks like I paid more for the Lodge name, rather than any added or superior benefits over the Camp Chef version. However it's not really something that I would waste time trying to return through the mail because the advantages of the Camp Chef version over this one are minimal. If I had to do it all over again, knowing what I know now, I would probably have purchased the 14-inch Camp Chef version over the A5DLL, but then I would be giving up 2 inches in length which is better for ground cooking as opposed to table cooking.Camp Chef Professional Dutch oven Lid Lifter (Black, 9-Inch)Pros:This one is the best for dutch oven table cooking because of its length. It keeps you from having the move the ovens around on the table in an awkward position because the length is just right.The handle on the Camp Chef has more of a solid feel than the Lodge Deluxe A5DLL version. The parallel bar configuration works the best for me.The weld junctions on the Camp Chef are better and it has a slightly more beefier construction than the Lodge Deluxe A5DLL. However, the lodge A5 has the best welds (read: more durability) of all three lifters that I own.Cons:The only con I can see at this point is that the metal is exposed under the outer sleeve of the t-handle (I assume to make it slide better inside the sleeve) on the Camp Chef. There could be a rusting issue somewhere down the line... then again maybe not because it looks like that part is galvanized. Only time will tell. There really is no need for this portion to be unfinished, because part of the bar that slides within the tube is finished and it does not hinder the way the bar functions at all.Final thoughts:Overall I like the traditional A5 the best but that is just my personal preference because of its multi-functional versatility. It's just a jack of all trades. I can do almost everything the deluxe lifters can do, plus I can use it as a fire poker and a coal raker.If you are cooking over a campfire, go with the A-5. If your cooking is limited only to cooking on a dutch oven table, then I would go with the 9-inch Camp Chef lifter. If you are ground or bean-hole cooking then I would take a long look at both the Camp Chef 14-inch and 22-inch lid lifters before deciding to buy this Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid Lifter.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 28, 2013', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great', 'author': 'Deron L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Works as it should', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 15, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nice & Heavy', 'author': 'RSKate', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Love this bag! It is heavy canvas with very sturdy straps for carrying. So adjust your expectations based on the stated specs of the product and common sense, I guess?', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 3, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Heads and shoulders above the rest!', 'author': 'silverwingit', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This a top-notch case for Dutch Ovens. The zipper is also heavy duty and the padding is thick enough to support the case when it's empty, which facilitates inserting a heavy pot because you have to struggle to keep the case open while holding a heavy Dutch Oven -- with only two hands. I think that would make it easier to carry. Carrying a heavy Dutch Oven top-up is awkward and harder on the back and shoulder than if was oriented side-up.The quality of this case compelled me to look into other Readywares products. title: Lodge Lid Lifter, 16", Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect', 'author': 'Randy', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Works great. Allows you to hold lid to get coals off the top by tilting it. Easy to use. Keeps your hand away from the heat. Definitely recommend', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars You Need One!', 'author': 'Linda', 'rating': 5, 'content': "If you like to cook outdoors in a Dutch oven, you really need one of these! Yes, you can use a hammer, or a stick or some wire, but this is SO much better! When you lift the lid, you aren't going to have ashes (or charcoal) fall in your food. The grip is secure and solid making is so easy to use. It stands upright when you aren't using it, so you won't lose it. This would make a great gift as well.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 15, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Good quality', 'author': 'Edward Smith', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Well made item, stands up to the weight of cast iron. Very impressed.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Lid lifter', 'author': 'Husky Fix', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Works great', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Works awesome', 'author': 'john rassler', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'It is way nicer than the standard kid lifters', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 16, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Good quality', 'author': 'M. Rohde', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is a good quality lifter that is easy to use. Unlike other lifters you can grab the lid and really have good control of your dutch oven.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 25, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I broke up with my other lid lifter for you, Lodge Deluxe', 'author': "Outdoorsy Boy's Mom", 'rating': 5, 'content': 'My plain old traditional lid lifter is pissed. It has served me on quite a few campouts but has recently been upstaged by this Lodge Deluxe lid lifter. At this week\'s campfire cooking event this new deluxe lid lifter frequently went "missing" as it was happily used by others who pitched their plain lid lifters off into the grass in favor of mine. I\'m pretty sure the old lid lifters conspired to retaliate because they tripped us up constantly as they seemed to be everywhere we stepped and their all-black bodies were impossible to spot in the dark. The bright yellow handles on this deluxe lid lifter made it easy to locate in the flickering firelight, especially with it\'s long, leggy shape that free-stands on its own. At the end of the night the deluxe model held on firmly as I swung my dutch oven lid completely upside down to return the coals on top of it to the fire, obviously sparking jealousy from the older lid lifters who previously had so much fun dropping the lid on my toe when I attempted such a move. Those cantankerous old lid lifters have all been demoted to fire log pokes and marshmallow roasters. Break up with your old lid lifter and upgrade to a real tool who knows how to treat you right!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect birthday gift for my outdoor chef', 'author': 'Kathe', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Campfire and woodstove cooking with cast iron cookware.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Slightly Worse than the Camp Chef verson plus it costs more', 'author': 'Brian J. F.', 'rating': 3, 'content': "I have three lifters to compare. They are the traditional styled Lodge A5 Camp Dutch Oven Lid Lifter, this Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid Lifter, and the Camp Chef Professional Dutch Oven Lid Lifter (Black, 9-Inch). Here is my unbiased opinion of all three.Lodge A5 Camp Dutch Oven Lid LifterPros:This is a multi-purpose item and it surprisingly has the best finish & has the least sloppily welded junctions of all three lifters.I say this is a multi-purpose item because the two deluxe lifters are pretty much dedicated dutch oven table / charcoal cooking items. If you are cooking over a campfire I would go with the A5 because it can be used as a fire poker, and a coal rake as well as a lid lifter.The A5 lifter is just as good as the Camp Chef when it comes to carrying a dutch oven by the bail handle over long distances because of the T-handle portion that is welded to the handle. The Deluxe Lodge A5DLL lifter is slightly worse because of the odd downward slope of the handle.Cons:The A5 does not have a cushioned handle like the other two.There is more of a learning curve as far as balancing the lid is concerned.... But not as drastic as other reviewers would lead you to believe unless you are truly an uncoordinated klutz. Yes, the deluxe lifters are both more stable when it comes to controlling the lid, but as of right now, the only major thing I can do with the other lifters that I cannot do with the traditional A5 is grab the lid and turn it completely upside down. Unless you are a tricked out dutch oven stunt cooking artist, then there is really no need to do this. I'm still able to use the A5 to tilt the lid to either side to knock the ashes off and whatever else I need to do while cooking and transporting (by the bail handle) the ovens. The point, I am trying to make is that the A5 is not as bad as people try to make it out to be.Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid LifterPros:This one has the best length for ground cooking. That is about the only good advantage that this one has over the rest of them, however, if you plan on doing deep bean hole type cooking, then I would go with the Camp Chef Professional Dutch Oven Lid Lifter, 22-Inch (which I do not own, but looks identical to the 9-inch which I do own).Cons:The finish on this model is the worst of the three. It is almost as if they baked on the finish and then tried to weld it together after the fact... as opposed to the Camp Chef which looks like it was welded first... then baked on the finished (which is how I would expect the process to be done). Then inner bar of the A5DLL Deluxe wiggles and turns inside the outer sleeve much more so than the Camp Chef, which is very annoying.I am not sure I am all that sold on the downward slope of the A5DLL handle as opposed to the straight, parallel handle configuration of the Camp Chef.To me, this is the worst lifter... and it cost the most. Looks like I paid more for the Lodge name, rather than any added or superior benefits over the Camp Chef version. However it's not really something that I would waste time trying to return through the mail because the advantages of the Camp Chef version over this one are minimal. If I had to do it all over again, knowing what I know now, I would probably have purchased the 14-inch Camp Chef version over the A5DLL, but then I would be giving up 2 inches in length which is better for ground cooking as opposed to table cooking.Camp Chef Professional Dutch oven Lid Lifter (Black, 9-Inch)Pros:This one is the best for dutch oven table cooking because of its length. It keeps you from having the move the ovens around on the table in an awkward position because the length is just right.The handle on the Camp Chef has more of a solid feel than the Lodge Deluxe A5DLL version. The parallel bar configuration works the best for me.The weld junctions on the Camp Chef are better and it has a slightly more beefier construction than the Lodge Deluxe A5DLL. However, the lodge A5 has the best welds (read: more durability) of all three lifters that I own.Cons:The only con I can see at this point is that the metal is exposed under the outer sleeve of the t-handle (I assume to make it slide better inside the sleeve) on the Camp Chef. There could be a rusting issue somewhere down the line... then again maybe not because it looks like that part is galvanized. Only time will tell. There really is no need for this portion to be unfinished, because part of the bar that slides within the tube is finished and it does not hinder the way the bar functions at all.Final thoughts:Overall I like the traditional A5 the best but that is just my personal preference because of its multi-functional versatility. It's just a jack of all trades. I can do almost everything the deluxe lifters can do, plus I can use it as a fire poker and a coal raker.If you are cooking over a campfire, go with the A-5. If your cooking is limited only to cooking on a dutch oven table, then I would go with the 9-inch Camp Chef lifter. If you are ground or bean-hole cooking then I would take a long look at both the Camp Chef 14-inch and 22-inch lid lifters before deciding to buy this Lodge A5DLL Deluxe Lid Lifter.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 28, 2013', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great', 'author': 'Deron L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Works as it should', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 15, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

The zipper is also heavy duty and the padding is thick enough to support the case when it's empty, which facilitates inserting a heavy pot because you have to struggle to keep the case open while holding a heavy Dutch Oven -- with only two hands. I think that would make it easier to carry. Carrying a heavy Dutch Oven top-up is awkward and harder on the back and shoulder than if was oriented side-up.The quality of this case compelled me to look into other Readywares products. title: Stainless Steel Replacement handle for Le Creuset,Aldi,Lodge, and other Enameled Cast-Iron Dutch Oven (2)
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great replacement for Le Creuset handles.', 'author': 'Andy Peeler', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Got a pair of these for far less than one handle for my big Le Creuset pot that had the plastic handle that was starting to leave fibers behind and become scratchy. Installed easily, looks good, works great for my pot I used for baking bread at 500 degrees, and now I have a spare handle for another pot.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 18, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect for using dutch oven in the oven', 'author': 'Needs Caffeine', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I have a nice Cuisinart dutch oven that came with a plastic knob. Several recipes required it cook in the oven at 450 degrees/broil and I read conflicting reports about the heat limit of those plastic knobs. I went out and bought a Lodge dutch oven with a metal knob, which is a great dutch oven, but small. I couldn't believe I hadn't thought to explore whether the knob could be changed. It can, aha, and so I bought this and screwed it onto the old, larger Cuisinart, and voila, now I can use it at high temps in the oven. Can't believe I hadn't thought of this before. This knob is perfect -- fits great, goes on snug and looks high end. Wish I hadn't spent all the money for another dutch oven when I could have just bought a knob. Ha, what a knob.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars WORKING', 'author': 'James D. My friend was surprised and very please with this gift.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 20, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Roasts just like the big name pans', 'author': 'Razz Man', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I needed a large, dutch oven for my big holiday meal and I didn't want to spend a lot of money. This was a terrific option. I own both Le Cruset and Staub, cast pots which I love. I cringed at the thought of paying $300-$400 for the size and shape I wanted from the French manufacturers. And, yes, this is made in China. This might have you saying, you get what you pay for. In the case of this oven, I feel I got way more than I paid for and then some. I used it for several meals, stews and chilis. It sat very nicely on my high BTU burner for searing my stew meat, then went right in the oven. It cleaned up nicely every time I used it for both searing and brazing.I guess the only complaint, or caveat would be, check out the weight capacity of your oven racks. I have a better quality, GE gas range/convection oven, and the rack really bowed due to the shear weight of this dutch oven filled with stew. I found another wire shelf from another appliance and set it on top of that rack with the support rails perpendicular to the oven rack. This was the extra support the rack needed. Without doubling up on the oven rack, I was afraid the welds were gong to snap on the rack wires.This isn't the pan's fault, but it does speak to the heft of this product", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 3, 2016', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Works Like A Charm', 'author': 'Mark D. I was saving up for a La Creuset, but they cost and arm and a leg, so I found this pot and bought it. I can highly recommend this unit to all who look at it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 6, 2020', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Stanbroil Stainless Steel Folding Finish Camp Dutch Oven Lid Stand, Pot Stand for Campfire Cooking Complete with Heat Resistant
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Versatile, Durable and space saving!', 'author': 'Paula B Campin', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The media could not be loaded. I have purchased several of these over the years because they are so handy to have when Dutch Oven cooking outdoors. I keep finding new ways to use them. This one is a bit tight to open and close but don't worry. It's new and will loosen up with use.As I said in the video, this product saves space in two different ways. First, it folds flat for easy storage and I can tuck it away in my bag of cast iron gear. Second, it allows me to take just one set of pots and pans camping instead of two. I no longer need to carry footed dutch ovens for my campfire cooking and flat bottom pans to use on the camp stove. This little stand allows me to use a flat bottom dutch oven outdoors to do my cooking. It also works as a handy lid stand so your lid stays clean when you're tending to a cooking pot. Now flip your cast iron lid over and place it on the stand and you have a griddle surface from which to cook. Be aware that not all cast iron lids will work as a griddle so you have to be careful when selecting your cast iron. Are you getting the picture as to why I have several of these? I just reduced the amount of gear I carry and saved many pounds of weight! Even if you don't use it with your cast iron, it works well with any type of cooking gear as a lid stand or to make an outdoor burner for the campfire. I have one more way that I use this item at home. I stack cast iron dutch ovens up in the corner of my kitchen as a decorative element and as a storage space in plain site. I place this under the bottom pan to raise the stack of pans from the floor so that I can easily run the vacuum cleaner and keep the dust bunnies at bay. This little gem is versatile!I would buy it again because I am always finding a new way to use it! If this is as clear as mud, watch the video for a visual explanation.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 31, 2018', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect for my water dispenser', 'author': 'Mukko', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Durable, simple, and good quality.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 2, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A place to put your hot lid!', 'author': 'Sandra Thompson', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'We like to cook with our cast iron dutch oven while camping. title: Marquette Castings 6 qt. Enameled Cast Iron Dutch Oven (Superior Blue)
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Impressed!!', 'author': 'Lela U.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I ordered this dutch oven in blue, a really beautiful color. It was not until I unboxed it did I realize that it was 13.8 pounds! Considering the pot that I was replacing weighs 2.5 pounds, I find it difficult for me to lift it up off the burner, carry it over to the sink, then hold it over the sink to drain contents. The other problem which arose when I needed to stir the contents, the lid is large and bulky to lay it down. Our counter top is quartz and not made for that type of heat. Also, storage is a slight problem due to the size, which I hadn't thought of earlier. Now, about the cooking. From boiling water for pasta to browning meat, it aces the job. Nice handle on top, relatively easy to wash and I like the fact the handles are a part of the casting, rather than bolted to the pot. The handles do get hot. It seems to cook faster than aluminum or stainless steel with even cooking. Serves a lot of purposes, it can even bake bread. I give it a fill 5 stars because it made extremely well. Because I haven't had it long, I do not know how well it will retain its finish or if it will eventually fleck off. Defintely worth the price.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Dutch Oven recently arrived and put to work!', 'author': 'KC', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I inherited my grandmothers large cast iron dutch oven, but it has a lot of very rough edges on the bottom that will cause damage to our new induction top. So, in my search I came upon this manufacturer, Marquette. After reading reviews of other dutch oven manufactures, I decided this is the one for me. I loved the beautiful finish inside and out, straight sides of the pot, excellent grip handles, cleans up well and it's at a good price point. Although the dutch oven is an American company it's made in China ( I wish it was made in the USA! ) which kept the price down from the French manufactures. In my opinion, I believe this company made great strides to over see the product and make quality product. I will agree with another reviewer that the lid knob is a bit sharp, but it certainly doesn't take away all the positives of this pot.In all fairness I do own a smaller piece of LC for a number of years.I would not hesitate to give this Marquette Dutch Oven as gift, great choice of colors and it came beautifully boxed.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 31, 2019', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars My new favorite thing in my kitchen', 'author': 'Kelly Kohn', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I love this dutch oven! cleans up nice. Works on my induction stove top and in the oven. So easy to clean! Really great Quality! It is perfect size we have a family of four and it is big enough to accommodate double batch recipes. The handles are good size also (this is something I was worried about). It is really pretty too. The sides are nice and straight and easy to seen in when cooking. The lid has ridges on the inside to help with self basting. The only thing I would change about this is the handle, I would prefer a more round type handle because it would be more comfortable to hold. Highly recommend this dutch oven.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 25, 2020', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "4.0 out of 5 stars Attractive piece of cookware that won't break the bank (with comparison to another pot)", 'author': 'Colonel K0rn', 'rating': 4, 'content': "The media could not be loaded. So I had a new recipe (Roasted Chicken Noodle Soup) that I wanted to try for a few years, and it suggested the use of a Dutch Oven. I couldn't bring myself to part with 3 Benjamins for a LeCruset, because I wasn't familiar with the different manufacturers of cookware, and the alternatives available. Additionally, my wife choked on her drink when she saw the price of them, and laughed like I had lost my mind.I had decent results without using a Dutch Oven with the recipe, but I wanted to use what the recipe called for. We were in the grocery store, and saw that they had a Lodge Enamelled Cast Iron 6 qt on sale, and the color matched most of our appliances (red). I purchased it, and used it twice, and I while perusing Amazon the other day, saw that I could get the same one for $10 less. Well, I had a bit of buyer's remorse, and read the reviews for the same model, and saw that a lot of customers were complaining about the coating flaking off, and there were several pictures to support their reviews. At the bottom of the page, the listing for the Marquette product came up, so I clicked on the link. Initially, I liked what I saw, and there were multiple reviews with a 5 star rating. Pretty impressive, but when there's less than 100 reviews, compared to thousands for the other products, it made me wonder why they were getting such good reviews, compared to the other alternatives. It turns out they are a new company, looking to get into an established industry, with new and attractive designs for their products. I have to say, the logo caught my eye. Additionally, the fact that they offer a lifetime warranty on the pot is another reason that I chose to purchase this product. Not many guys think about what their cookware looks like, but aesthetics does play an important role for the customer, as well as the warranty. Nobody wants to bring a ratty casserole dish to the potluck, or have it crap out after a couple of uses.I did a video of the unboxing and comparison to the Lodge model of the same capacity, and have attached it to this written review. I gave the product 4 stars for the lid. I know it's not supposed to sit flush to allow for some venting, but I was expecting it to sit evenly across the circumference. My video review shows this in effect. It's almost like the lid is warped, but I know cast iron doesn't warp. I'm not sure if this is an intentional design.The Lodge does claim to be a self-basting product, with the design of the lid, and judging by the design of the smaller circles on the lid, it would appear that the Marquette was designed to have condensation collect on the lid, and then drip back into the pot via these raised edges. Clever design.I do like the completely flat bottom, which will allow me to use it on our stovetop with the larger element, as compared to the smaller base of the Lodge. I also like the fact that the height is much lower than the Lodge, and I'm sure that I can get a whole chicken into the pot, without it touching the sides. The interior coating is very smooth, and the glazing of the exterior is very nice and rich. It looks like a very high quality piece of cookware. I would prefer to purchase a product that was designed and manufactured in the USA, even if it meant spending a few dollars more.I'll update the written review once I make my next dish, and hope that it performs as expected.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Really great and a fraction of the cost of the high end ones that seem just as good.', 'author': 'Joey Sawyer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Dutch ovens are great and this one checks all the boxes. Easy to clean. Easy to grab handles. Color is really pretty', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 7, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Size is Perfect, But Not too Heavy', 'author': 'Lee Ann', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Perfect size, perfect color, not too heavy. I did burn some veggies a bit in the middle it scrubbed put very well. Dont need to use a high heat! Perfect for baking bread loaves with parchment paper. Love how it looks over all on top of my stove!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 17, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect results, beautiful color. It revived my waning interest in cooking after 35 years...', 'author': 'Susanne C.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Having compared reviews on Dutch Ovens, I decided on this one. My previous experience with Dutch Ovens was limited to my old Magnalite 12 quart which is fine in the oven but too large for convenient stovetop browning. The color (blue) is really beautiful, and I prefer the straight sides to the more curved types. Within the first few days I made a beef stew and a roast chicken, both turned out perfectly and the Dutch oven cleaned up very easily. The quality of the resulting pan gravies were far superior to those obtained with other methods. I cannot imagine a need to pay more for fancier brands. We have a large family of adults ar home and I hope Marquette castings comes out with a slightly larger version soon.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful Baked Beans and other stews', 'author': 'Michael Collins', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Product is sturdy and works wonderfully; easy top use and easy to clean up.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 15, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars If you‚Äôre looking for a Dutch oven - this is the one', 'author': 'PDXGretch', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'This is a gorgeous Dutch oven. I received it as a Christmas present this past year. I love the color, the enameled interior makes it easy to clean (and no need to season for use), it heats evenly on both our gas cooktop and in our electric oven, and the wide looped handles make it very easy to grasp to pick up even when using pot holders or oven mitts. Plus, after 16 years living as a Michigander, I love that this is a Michigan company! The only reason for the reduction in rating (I wish there was a way to make it 4.5 stars) is the knob on the lid. It is metal and rectangular in shape to accommodate the company logo, and as other reviewers have also mentioned the corners are SO SHARP - to a point where I‚Äôve wondered if it might be helpful to use a dremmel to file the corners down some. I‚Äôve also considered purchasing a new knob from another manufacturer to replace it. This issue does not keep me from enjoying this beautiful Dutch oven, though - and after a winter of fairly heavy use for soups, stews, chili, and Dutch oven bread I know this well-made Marquette Castings pot will be a favorite in our kitchen for years to come.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 14, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Marquette Castings versus Le Creuset-same meal.', 'author': 'Scott W. Beckerley', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I cooked my Christmas dinner in this, a pot roast. I cooked a second pot roast in my other 6 qt Dutch oven, a Le Creuset. Both performed well but, with some marked differences. The Marquette Castings oven handles stayed cooler to the touch for a longer period of time during cooking and the roast also cooked more quickly and made a thicker gravy. The Le Creuset took about 45 minutes longer to cook a similar size roast and I had to use slightly higher heat to get the gravy to thicken. Also, the Marquette lid seems to fit more tightly. There was also no sticking of anything to the bottom, while the Le Creuset had a little meat that stuck to it. Perhaps because it was the first use for the Marquette. I have had the Le Creuset for about 5 years. As it was a discontinued colour and I paid only a little more for it than this pot, I would put them pretty even. If I paid the full retail (about three times as much), I would favor this pot. So, it's a standoff until the Marquette ages a bit. I am very curious to see how that works out due to the super affordable price. Time will tell but, very happy with it on this first outing.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 26, 2017', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Visions Dutch Oven Casserole 5L
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Very Shock Resistant, Lasts a Lifetime, Cooks Great', 'author': 'Kenneth W. Rohla', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have been using Corning Visionware for about 40 years and I love it. Got this pot to replace one my wife dropped on a hard tile floor. I have had a large full set of Visionware for about 40 years and they are very durable, work well, and I have never had one break from thermal shock. You can take these from the freeser to the stove, or from the stove to cold water with no problems. Whomever invented this material is a genius. It is nontoxic, and you can see your food cooking through the pot ‚Äî very handy.This 5 liter Dutch oven is big enough for a large pot of food but not so big, cumbersome, and hard to store as larger stock pots.
